הַחֶבְרָה מְתַכְנֶנֶת לְטַוָּח אָרֹךְ בַּשּׁוּק.

examples.translation: I enjoyed the book I read.
They are enjoying the beach all day.

hanot.notes: Regular verb in binyan Nifal (נִפְעַל), often used for reflexive or passive actions, here indicating experiencing pleasure. The root ה.נ.ה relates to enjoyment or benefit, and לֵהָנוֹת is typically followed by מִן (min, 'from') to indicate the source of enjoyment.

idioms.usage: הִיא נֶהֱנֵית מֵהַרֶגַע בְּלִי לַחְשׁוֹב עַל מָחָר.

dayen.root_meaning: Related to judging, discussing, or debating

examples.translation: I discussed the new plan with him.
They are discussing in court now.

dayen.notes: Regular verb in binyan Piel (פִּעֵל), which often indicates an intensive or deliberate action. The root ד.י.ן relates to judging or debating, and לְדַיֵּן can mean 'to discuss,' 'to debate,' or 'to judge' depending on context, with 'discuss' being common in modern conversational Hebrew.

idioms.usage: הֵם דִּיְּנוּ עַל כָּל דָּבָר בְּפַגִּישָׁה אַחַת.

examples.translation: I shared my idea with the friends.
She is sharing the decisions with everyone.

shatef.notes: Regular verb in binyan Piel (פִּעֵל), which often indicates an intensive or causative action. The root שׁ.ת.ף relates to partnership or collaboration, and לְשַׁתֵּף can mean 'to share' (e.g., information, feelings), 'to involve' (e.g., in a process), or 'to collaborate' depending on context.

idioms.usage: הַצּוֹוֶת שִׁתֵּף פְּעוּלָה לְהַצִּיל אֶת הַפְּרוֹיֶקְט.

bivtoach.root_meaning: Related to trust, security, or reliance

examples.translation: I trusted him completely.
She is trusting her friends.

bivtoach.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל), though the guttural ח affects vowel patterns (e.g., בּוֹטֵחַ instead of expected בּוֹטֵחֵ). The root ב.ט.ח relates to trust or security, and לִבְטוֹחַ is often followed by בְּ (be-, 'in') to indicate the object of trust.

idioms.translation: trusting in the shadow of his wings (biblical, relying on divine protection)
idioms.usage: הוּא בּוֹטֵחַ בְּצֵל כְּנָפָיו שֶׁל הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא.

examples.translation: I celebrated my birthday at the restaurant.

examples.hebrew: הֵם מְחַגְּגִים אֶת הַחַג בְּבֵית הַכְּנֶסֶת.
examples.transliteration: Hem mechagim et ha-chag be-veit ha-kneset.
examples.translation: They are celebrating the holiday at the synagogue.

chageg.notes: Regular verb in binyan Piel (פִּעֵל), which often indicates an intensive or deliberate action. The root ח.ג.ג relates to festivity or celebration, and לְחַגֵּג is commonly used for both formal holidays (e.g., חַג) and personal events like birthdays or achievements.

idioms.usage: הֵם חִגְּגוּ בִּגְדוֹלּוֹת אַחֲרֵי הַנִּצָּחוֹן.

examples.translation: I changed my mind about the topic.

examples.hebrew: הֵם מְשַׁנִּים אֶת הַתָּכְנִית כָּל שָׁנָה.
examples.transliteration: Hem meshanim et ha-tochnit kol shana.
examples.translation: They are changing the plan every year.

shanot.notes: Regular verb in binyan Piel (פִּעֵל), which often indicates an intensive or deliberate action. The root שׁ.נ.ה relates to change or repetition (also linked to 'shana,' year), and לְשַׁנּוֹת is used for both tangible (e.g., objects) and intangible (e.g., opinions) changes.

idioms.usage: הוּא שִׁנָּה אֶת עוֹרוֹ וְהָיָה לְאָדָם טוֹב יוֹתֵר.

examples.translation: I saved the child from the water.
They are saving the project from failure.

hatzil.notes: Regular verb in binyan Hifil (הִפְעִיל), which often indicates a causative action. The root נ.צ.ל relates to rescue or deliverance, and לְהַצִּיל is used for both physical (e.g., saving a life) and abstract (e.g., saving a situation) contexts.

idioms.translation: saved in the nick of time
idioms.usage: הוּא הִצִּיל אֶת הַמַּצָּב בְּעוֹד מוֹעֵד.

examples.translation: I agreed to give him help.
They are agreeing on this plan.

haskim.notes: Regular verb in binyan Hifil (הִפְעִיל), which often indicates a causative or active action. The root ס.כ.ם relates to agreement or consent, and לְהַסְכִּים is typically followed by לְ (le-, 'to') or עַל (al, 'on/about') to indicate what is agreed upon.

idioms.usage: הִיא הִסְכִּימָה בְּלֵב שָׁלֵם לָעֲזוֹר לָנוּ.

examples.translation: I hoped for peace in the country.
They are hoping for success in the project.

kavot.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל), though the guttural ו and ה affect vowel patterns slightly (e.g., קוֹוֶה instead of a typical Pa'al pattern). The root ק.ו.ה relates to hope or expectation, and לְקַוּוֹת is often followed by לְ (le-, 'for') to indicate what is hoped for.

idioms.usage: הוּא קִוָּה לַטּוֹב לַמְרוֹת הַמַּצָּב הַקָּשֶׁה.

examples.translation: I practiced for the race every day.
She is practicing for this performance.

hitamen.notes: Regular verb in binyan Hitpael (הִתְפַּעֵל), which often indicates reflexive or reciprocal action, here suggesting self-training or practice. The root א.מ.ן relates to training or skill-building, and לְהִתְאַמֵּן is commonly used for physical exercise, sports, or skill rehearsals.

idioms.usage: הוּא הִתְאַמֵּן לְלֹא הֶרֶף לִפְנֵי הַתַּחֲרוּת.

examples.translation: I answered his question quickly.
She is answering all the questions in class.

anot.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל), though the guttural ע affects vowel patterns (e.g., עוֹנֶה instead of a typical Pa'al pattern). The root ע.נ.ה relates to answering or responding, and לַעֲנוֹת is often followed by לְ (le-, 'to') to indicate the recipient or context of the response.

idioms.translation: answered with a small head (answered modestly)
idioms.usage: הוּא עָנָה בְּרֹאשׁ קָטָן כְּשֶׁשָּׁאֲלוּ אוֹתוֹ עַל הַזֹּאת.

examples.translation: I created a beautiful drawing with a pen.
They are creating original music.

tzor.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל), with the guttural צ slightly influencing vowel patterns (e.g., יוֹצֵר). The root י.צ.ר relates to creating or forming, and לִיצוֹר is used for artistic, practical, or conceptual creation, often implying an active process.

idioms.usage: הוּא יָצַר אֶת הָעֵסֶק מֵהָאֵפֶס בְּיָדָיו.

examples.translation: I joined their group.
She is joining the party tomorrow.

hitztaref.notes: Regular verb in binyan Hitpael (הִתְפַּעֵל), which often indicates reflexive or reciprocal action, here suggesting joining oneself to something or someone. The root צ.ר.ף relates to combining or attaching, and לְהִצְטָרֵף is typically followed by לְ (le-, 'to') to indicate what is being joined.

idioms.translation: joined the fray (joined the effort or fight)
idioms.usage: הוּא הִצְטָרֵף לַמַּעֲרָכָה לְשַׁפֵּר אֶת הַמַּצָּב.

akov.root_meaning: Related to following, tracking, or pursuing

examples.translation: I followed the teacher on the way.
He is following the news today.

akov.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל), with the guttural ע affecting vowel patterns (e.g., עוֹקֵב instead of a typical Pa'al pattern). The root ע.ק.ב relates to following or tracking, and לַעֲקֹב is often followed by אַחֲרֵי (acharei, 'after') or לְ (le-, 'to') to indicate what is being followed.

idioms.usage: הוּא עָקַב אַחֲרֵיהָ מִן הַצֵּל כְּדֵי לֹא לְהֵרָאוֹת.

examples.translation: I led the team to victory.
She is leading the project with confidence.

hovil.notes: Regular verb in binyan Hifil (הִפְעִיל), which often indicates a causative action, here meaning to cause others to follow or to guide. The root י.ב.ל (often appearing as ה.ב.ל in Hifil) relates to leading or bringing, and לְהוֹבִיל can be used literally (e.g., guiding people) or figuratively (e.g., leading a project).
similar_verbs: לִנְהוֹג (linhoG) - to lead (e.g., a vehicle or group)

idioms.translation: led at the head of the camp (took the forefront)
idioms.usage: הוּא הוֹבִיל בְּרֹאשׁ הַמַּחֲנֶה לְשֵׁנוּי חֶבְרָתִי.

examples.translation: I compared between the two products.
He is comparing the results now.

hashvot.notes: Regular verb in binyan Hifil (הִפְעִיל), which often indicates a causative action, here meaning to cause a comparison. The root שׁ.ו.ה relates to equating or making similar, and לְהַשְׁוִוֹת is typically followed by בֵּין (bein, 'between') for comparing two things or אֶת (et, 'with') for aligning with something.

idioms.translation: compared the heavens to the earth (exaggerated comparison)
idioms.usage: הוּא הִשְׁוָה אֶת הַשְּׁמַיִם לָאָרֶץ כְּשֶׁדִּבֵּר עַל הַהַבְדֵּל.

examples.translation: I protected the child from the danger.

examples.hebrew: הֵם מְגִינִים עַל הָעִיר בְּכָל הַלֵּב.
examples.transliteration: Hem meginim al ha-ir be-chol ha-lev.
examples.translation: They are protecting the city with all their heart.

hagen.notes: Regular verb in binyan Hifil (הִפְעִיל), which often indicates a causative action, here meaning to cause protection or defense. The root ג.נ.ן relates to guarding or shielding, and לְהָגֵן is typically followed by עַל (al, 'on/over') to indicate what is being protected.
related_words: גַּנָּן (ganan) - gardener (related root, protector of a garden)

idioms.usage: הוּא הֵגֵן בְּגוּפוֹ עַל הַיְּלָדִים בִּזְמַן הַסַּכָּנָה.

hodia.root_meaning: Related to knowing, understanding, or informing

examples.translation: I informed them about the change in the plan.

examples.hebrew: הַמּוֹרָה מוֹדִיעָה לַהוֹרִים עַל הַצְלָחוֹת הַתַּלְמִידִים.
examples.transliteration: Ha-morá modí’a la-horím al ha-hatzlachót ha-talmidím.
examples.translation: The teacher informs the parents about the students’ successes.

examples.hebrew: אוֹדִיעַ לְכֻלָּם אֶת הַחֲדָשׁוֹת בְּעוֹד שָׁעָה.
examples.transliteration: Odía le-kulám et ha-chadashót be-ód sha’á.
examples.translation: I will inform everyone of the news in an hour.

hodia.notes: Hif'il is the causative form of Pa'al, shifting 'to know' into 'to cause to know' or 'to inform'. It’s one of the most common forms for this root in modern Hebrew, widely used for notifying or reporting, contrasting with Pi’el’s less frequent 'to inform' (יִדֵּעַ).

idioms.usage: הוּא הוֹדִיעַ בְּרֹאשׁ חָדָשׁ עַל הַתָּכְנִית הַחֲדָשָׁה. (He informed with a fresh start about the new plan.)

meaning: to be caused to be known

examples.translation: I participated in the annual competition.
They are participating in an important meeting.

hishtatef.notes: Regular verb in binyan Hitpael (הִתְפַּעֵל), which often indicates reflexive or reciprocal action, here suggesting involving oneself in an activity or group. The root שׁ.ת.ף relates to sharing or partnership, and לְהִשְׁתַּתֵּף is typically followed by בְּ (be-, 'in') to indicate what is being participated in.

idioms.usage: הִיא הִשְׁתַּתְּפָה בְּשִׂמְחָה בַּחֲתוּנָה שֶׁלָּהֶם.

examples.hebrew: חָגַגְתִּי אֶת חַג הַפֶּסַח עִם מִשְׁפַּחְתִּי.
examples.transliteration: Chagagti et chag ha-Pesach im mishpachti.
examples.translation: I celebrated Passover with my family.

examples.hebrew: הֵם חוֹגְגִים אֶת יוֹם הָעַצְמָאוּת בָּרְחוֹבוֹת.
examples.transliteration: Hem chogGim et yom ha-atzma’ut ba-rechovot.
examples.translation: They are celebrating Independence Day in the streets.

chagot.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל), with the guttural ח affecting vowel patterns (e.g., חוֹגֵג instead of a typical Pa'al pattern). The root ח.ג.ה relates to festivity or holidays, and לְחַגּוֹת is often used specifically for observing holidays or special occasions, distinguishing it slightly from לְחַגֵּג (Piel), which has a broader celebratory connotation.

idioms.translation: celebrated the holiday as it should be
idioms.usage: הֵם חָגְגוּ אֶת הַחַג כָּרָאוּי עִם תְּפִלּוֹת וְסְעוּדוֹת.

examples.translation: I explored the new city on foot.
They are exploring the phenomenon in the lab.

chakor.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל), with the guttural ח affecting vowel patterns (e.g., חוֹקֵר). The root ח.ק.ר relates to investigation or exploration, and לַחְקוֹר can mean to explore physically (e.g., a place) or intellectually (e.g., research). It’s often followed by אֶת (et) to indicate the object of exploration.

idioms.usage: הוּא חָקַר עַד הַסּוֹף אֶת הַתְּעוּקָה הַמּוּזָרָה.

examples.translation: I relaxed after a busy day at work.

examples.hebrew: הִיא נִרְגַּעַת עַל הַחוֹף בְּשַׁעַת הַשְּׁקִיעָה.
examples.transliteration: Hi nirga’at al ha-chof be-sha’at ha-shki’a.
examples.translation: She is relaxing on the beach at sunset.

hiraga.notes: Regular verb in binyan Nifal (נִפְעַל), which often indicates a passive or reflexive action, here suggesting calming oneself or becoming calm. The root ר.ג.ע relates to calmness or soothing, and לְהִרָגַע can stand alone or be followed by מִן (min, 'from') or עַל (al, 'on/at') to specify the context of relaxation.

idioms.translation: relaxed from the storm (calmed after turmoil)
idioms.usage: הוּא נִרְגַּע מִן הַסּוֹעָר אַחֲרֵי שֶׁהַבְּעָיָה נִפְתְּרָה.

examples.translation: I imagined how the new house would look.

examples.hebrew: הִיא דּוֹמָה אֶת הַחֲלוֹם שֶׁלָּהּ בְּכָל לֵילֶה.
examples.transliteration: Hi doma et ha-chalom shela be-chol leile.
examples.translation: She is imagining her dream every night.

damot.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל), with no guttural influences complicating its conjugation. The root ד.מ.ה relates to likeness or resemblance, and לְדַמּוֹת often means to picture something in the mind or liken one thing to another. It’s typically followed by אֵיךְ (eich, 'how') or אֶת (et) to specify what is being imagined.

idioms.usage: הוּא דָּמָה בְּדִמְיוֹנוֹ אֶת הָעֹלָם הַמּוּשְׁלָם.

examples.translation: I smiled when I saw the picture.
She is smiling at everyone with joy.

chayech.notes: Regular verb in binyan Piel (פִּעֵל), which often indicates an intensive or deliberate action, here the act of smiling. The root ח.י.ך (sometimes derived from ח.י.ה, 'to live') relates to cheerfulness or expression, and לְחַיֵּךְ can stand alone or be followed by לְ (le-, 'to/at') to indicate the recipient of the smile.
related_words: חֵן (chen) - charm, grace (related to pleasant expression)

idioms.usage: הוּא חִיֵּךְ מֵאֹזֶן לְאֹזֶן כְּשֶׁשָּׁמַע אֶת הַבְּשׂוֹרָה.

examples.translation: I collected the books from the table.
They are collecting donations for the poor.

esof.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל), with the guttural א affecting vowel patterns (e.g., אוֹסֵף). The root א.ס.ף relates to gathering or collecting, and לֶאֱסוֹף is often followed by אֶת (et) to indicate what is being collected, or used with מֵ (me-, 'from') to specify the source.

idioms.usage: אַחֲרֵי הַפְּרֵידָה, הִיא אָסְפָה אֶת הַשְּׁבָרִים וְהִתְחִילָה מֵחָדָשׁ.

examples.translation: I dreamed about a trip around the world.

examples.hebrew: הִיא חוֹלֶמֶת עַל עָתִיד טוֹב יוֹתֵר.
examples.transliteration: Hi cholemet al atid tov yoter.
examples.translation: She is dreaming of a better future.

chalom.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל), with the guttural ח affecting vowel patterns (e.g., חוֹלֵם). The root ח.ל.ם relates to dreaming, either in sleep or as an aspiration, and לַחֲלוֹם is often followed by עַל (al, 'about') to specify the content of the dream.

idioms.usage: הוּא חָלַם בְּעֵרֶב עַל הַזֹּאת בְּמֶשֶׁךְ כָּל הַיּוֹם.

examples.translation: I shone light into the room with a lamp.
The sun is shining on the mountains of Jerusalem.

ha’ir.notes: Regular verb in binyan Hifil (הִפְעִיל), which often indicates a causative action, here meaning to cause light to shine or to illuminate. The root א.ו.ר relates to light, and לְהָאִיר can be used literally (e.g., to light up) or figuratively (e.g., to enlighten). It’s often followed by אֶת (et) with an object or עַל (al, 'on') to specify what is illuminated.

idioms.usage: הוּא הֵאִיר פָּנִים כְּשֶׁשָּׁמַע אֶת הַחֲדָשׁוֹת.

examples.translation: He sent a letter to a friend.
They send shipments worldwide.

shalach.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root ש.ל.ח is associated with sending or dispatching. It is commonly used in everyday Hebrew, both in literal and figurative contexts.
similar_verbs: לְהוֹצִיא (lehotzi) - to send out, to issue

idioms.translation: to reach out (often in the context of harming)
idioms.usage: הוּא לֹא יָכוֹל לְשַׁלֵּחַ יָד בְּרֵכָה.

idioms.translation: cast your bread (do good without expecting return)
idioms.usage: שָׁלַח לַחְמְךָ עַל פְּנֵי הַמַּיִם.

examples.translation: He sold his car.
They are selling fruits at the market.

machar.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root מ.כ.ר is associated with selling or commerce. It's a common verb used in everyday Hebrew when talking about selling items, services, or even abstract concepts like selling an idea.
similar_verbs: לְמַכֵּר (lemaker) - to market, to sell extensively

idioms.usage: הוּא מָכַר אֶת נַפְשׁוֹ בִּשְׁבִיל כֶּסֶף.
הוּא מָכַר לִי סַפִּירוֹת וְלֹא קִיֵּם.

examples.translation: Please describe the problem.
She described the landscape in detail.

taar.notes: Regular verb in binyan Piel (פִּעֵל), which often indicates an intensive or causative action. The root ת.א.ר is associated with forms and descriptions. לְתָאֵר is used when providing details or explanations about something.

idioms.usage: תֵּאֵר לְךָ מָה יָכוֹל לִקְרוֹת.

examples.translation: He finished reading the book.
They are finishing the work today.

gamar.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root ג.מ.ר signifies completion or ending. This verb is commonly used to indicate the completion of tasks, activities, or periods of time.
similar_verbs: לְהַגִּיעַ לְסוֹף (lehagia lesof) - to reach the end

idioms.usage: הוּא גָּמַר אוֹמֶר לְנַסּוֹת דָּבָר חָדָשׁ.
הַחֹזֶה גָּמַר בְּהֶסְכֵּם שְׁנֵי הַצְּדָדִים.

examples.translation: She is wearing a beautiful dress.
I wore new clothes to the party.

lilbosh.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל). The root ל.ב.ש relates to clothing and wearing garments. **לִלְבּוֹשׁ** is used when talking about putting on clothes or simply wearing them. It's a commonly used verb in everyday Hebrew.
related_words: מַלְבִּישׁ (malbísh) - dresser, one who clothes (Hifil binyan)
similar_verbs: לִנְעֹל (lin'ól) - to wear shoes, to lock
לַעֲטוֹת (la'atót) - to wear (formal attire), to cloak

idioms.usage: הַפְּרוֹיֶקְט לָבַשׁ פָּנִים חֲדָשׁוֹת לְאַחַר הַשִּׁנּוּיִים.

idioms.translation: wears the heart on the sleeve
idioms.usage: הוּא לוֹבֵשׁ אֶת הַלֵּב עַל הַשִּׁרְוּל וּמַרְגִּישׁ כָּךְ.

examples.translation: Please bring the book.
She brought a cake to the party.

lehavi.notes: The verb **להביא** (*lehavi*) is a regular verb in binyan **Hif'il** (הִפְעִיל), which often indicates a causative action. Here, it means 'to cause to come,' i.e., to bring. The root letters ב.ו.א generally relate to 'coming' or 'entering' (as in the verb **לָבוֹא** - 'to come'). **להביא** is commonly used in daily speech for bringing objects, people, or even abstract concepts.

idioms.translation: brought him up to here (to this point)
idioms.usage: הַנִּסָּיוֹן הֵבִיא אוֹתוֹ עַד הֲלֹם.
הוּא הֵבִיא עַל עַצְמוֹ אֶת הַצָּרוֹת.

examples.hebrew: הוּא מְבַקֵּר אֶת הַהוֹרִים בְּכָל שַׁבָּת.
examples.transliteration: Hu mevakér et ha-horim bechol Shabbat.
examples.translation: He visits his parents every weekend.
We visited the art museum.

levaker.notes: The verb **לְבַקֵּר** (*levaker*) is a regular verb in the **Piel** (פִּעֵל) binyan, which often indicates an intensive or frequentative action. The root ב.ק.ר is associated with visiting, inspecting, or criticizing. In everyday Hebrew, **לְבַקֵּר** is commonly used to talk about visiting places or people. It can also mean 'to criticize' in a different context.

idioms.usage: הַנָּשִׂיא בִּקֵּר פְּנֵי הַמֶּלֶךְ.
הַסּוֹפֵר בִּקֵּר בַּחֲמָה בּוּשֶׁם אֶת הַסֵּפֶר הֶחָדָשׁ.

examples.translation: I hear music on the radio.
She heard the good news.

lishmoa.notes: The verb **לִשְׁמוֹעַ** (*lishmoa*) is a regular verb in the **Pa'al** (פָּעַל) binyan. The root **שׁ.מ.ע** relates to hearing and listening. This verb is commonly used in everyday Hebrew to express the act of hearing sounds, listening to music, or paying attention to someone speaking.
related_words: לְהַשְׁמִיעַ (lehashmi'a) - to make heard, to announce

idioms.usage: בְּבַקָּשָׁה, שְׁמַע קוֹלִי וַעֲשֶׂה כְּמוֹ שֶׁאָמַרְתִּי.
זֶה שָׁמַע אַחַת שֶׁהוּא מוּמְחֶה בַּתַּחום.

leshalem.root_meaning: Related to peace, wholeness, or completion

examples.translation: She paid in cash for the meal.
We are paying the bill tomorrow.

leshalem.notes: The verb **לְשַׁלֵּם** (*leshalém*) is a regular verb in the **Piel** (פִּעֵל) binyan, which often indicates an intensive or causative action. The root **שׁ.ל.ם** relates to notions of completeness, wholeness, and peace. In the context of **לְשַׁלֵּם**, it means 'to fulfill an obligation' or 'to complete a payment,' hence 'to pay.' This verb is commonly used in everyday Hebrew when discussing financial transactions.

idioms.usage: הוּא סוֹפְסוֹף שִׁלֵּם אֶת הַחוֹב.
הוּא שִׁלֵּם בְּמִטְבּוֹ עַל הַטַּעֲוָה.

examples.translation: I get up early in the morning.
They got up and then began to walk.

lakum.notes: The verb **לָקוּם** (*lakum*) is an irregular verb in binyan **Pa'al** (פָּעַל). The root **ק.ו.ם** relates to rising, standing up, or arising. It is a hollow verb because the second root letter is **ו** (vav), which affects conjugation patterns. This verb is commonly used in everyday Hebrew when talking about getting up from sleep or standing up from a sitting position.
related_words: הִתְקוֹמֵם (hitkomem) - to rebel, to rise up

idioms.usage: קוּם עֲשֵׂה מַשֶּׁהוּ מוֹעִיל.
הַדָּבָר הַזֶּה לֹא יָקוּם וְלֹא יִהְיֶה.

examples.translation: I am walking to the park.
They walked to school in the morning.

lalechet.notes: This verb is in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל), the simple active form. The root ל-כ-ת overlaps with 'halach' (הָלַךְ), but 'laléchet' emphasizes the act of walking. The present tense uses forms of 'holech' (הוֹלֵךְ), which is more common in modern Hebrew.

idioms.usage: הוּא בָּחַר לָלֶכֶת בְּדַרְכּוֹ שֶׁל אָבִיו.
אָמַרְתִּי לוֹ 'לֵךְ לְךָ' כְּשֶׁהִתְרַגַּזְתִּי.

litzpot.root_meaning: Related to watching, observing, or expecting

examples.translation: I watch TV every evening.
She watched the rising sun.

litzpot.notes: This verb is in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל), the simple active form. The root צ-פ-ה relates to watching or expecting. In modern Hebrew, 'litzpot' is commonly used for watching (e.g., TV) and expecting (e.g., an event).

idioms.usage: הוּא עָמַד כְּצוֹפֶה מִן הַצַּד בִּמְקוֹם לְעַזּוֹר.
אֲנַחְנוּ צְרִיכִים לִצְפּוֹת לְעָתִיד טוֹב יוֹתֵר.

nifal.note: Less common in modern usage

lechayech.root_meaning: Related to smiling or showing happiness

examples.translation: He smiled when he saw the gift.

examples.hebrew: אֲנִי מְחַיֶּכֶת כָּל פַּעַם שֶׁאֲנִי חוֹשֶׁבֶת עָלָיו.
examples.transliteration: Ani mechayéchet kol pá’am she-ani choshévet aláv.
examples.translation: I smile every time I think about him.

lechayech.notes: This verb is in binyan Piel (פִּעֵל), which often intensifies or modifies the root’s meaning. The root ח-י-ך relates to smiling, derived from 'chai' (life) and expressions of joy. It’s a common modern Hebrew verb for smiling.

idioms.usage: הִיא חִיְּכָה מֵאֹזֶן לְאֹזֶן כְּשֶׁשָּׁמְעָה אֶת הַבְּשׂוֹרָה.
הוּא נִסָּה לְחַיֵּךְ בְּקוֹשִׁי לַמְרוֹת הַכְּאֵב.

hitpael.note: Often implies a subtle or inward smile

examples.translation: The child is crying because he’s tired.
She cried when she heard the news.

livkot.notes: This verb is in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל), the simple active form. The root ב-כ-ה is directly tied to crying or weeping, a common emotional expression in Hebrew. The guttural ה affects pronunciation slightly.

idioms.usage: לֹא כְּדַאי לִבְכּוֹת עַל הַחֲלָב הַשָּׁפוּךְ, מַה שֶּׁנַּעֲשָׂה נַעֲשָׂה.
הַתִּינוֹק בּוֹכֶה בְּקוֹל כִּי הוּא רָעֵב.

hifil.note: Less common but used in causative contexts

litzok.root_meaning: Related to shouting, crying out, or calling loudly

examples.translation: He shouted when he saw the danger.
The crowd shouts with joy at the game.

litzok.notes: This verb is in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל), the simple active form. The root צ-ע-ק involves a guttural ע (ayin), affecting pronunciation. It’s used for loud vocal expressions, whether out of fear, joy, or anger.
related_words: צַעֲקָן (tza’akán) - a loud or shouting person

idioms.usage: הוּא צָעַק עַד הַשָּׁמַיִם כְּשֶׁהִפְסִיד בַּמִּשְׂחָק.
הִיא צוֹעֶקֶת מִן הַלֵּב כְּשֶׁהִיא כּוֹעֶסֶת.

examples.hebrew: אֲנִי מְנַקֶּה אֶת הַבַּיִת כָּל יוֹם שִׁשִּׁי.
examples.transliteration: Ani menaké et ha-báyit kol yom shishí.
examples.translation: I clean the house every Friday.
They cleaned the windows in the morning.

lenakot.notes: This verb is in binyan Piel (פִּעֵל), which often intensifies or specifies the root’s action. The root נ-ק-ה relates to cleanliness or purification, and in Piel, it becomes an active process of cleaning. The guttural ה affects pronunciation slightly.

idioms.usage: הוּא נִקָּה אֶת הַשְּׁלוּחָה לִפְנֵי שֶׁהִתְחִיל לָעֲבֹד.
אֲנִי צָרִיךְ לְנַקּוֹת אֶת הָרֹאשׁ אַחֲרֵי יוֹם קָשֶׁה.

nifal.note: Common in passive contexts

hifil.note: Different root meaning, unrelated to cleaning

linhog.root_meaning: Related to driving, leading, or guiding

examples.translation: I drive to work every morning.

examples.hebrew: הִיא נָהֲגָה בְּמֶשֶׁךְ שָׁעָה לְלֹא הַפְסָקָה.
examples.transliteration: Hi nahagá bémeshech sha’á leló hafsaká.
examples.translation: She drove for an hour without stopping.

linhog.notes: This verb is in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל), the simple active form. The root נ-ה-ג relates to driving or leading, with modern usage focused on driving vehicles. It can also mean 'to behave' in different contexts, but 'to drive' is primary here. The guttural ה affects pronunciation.

idioms.usage: הוּא תָּמִיד נוֹהֵג בְּזָהִירוּת בַּדְּרָכִים.

idioms.translation: to drive with a soft hand (lead gently)
idioms.usage: הַמְּנַהֵל צָרִיךְ לִנְהוֹג בְּיָד רַכָּה עִם הָעוֹבְדִים.

nifal.note: Rare in modern Hebrew for driving

hifil.note: Shifts meaning to leadership rather than driving

lechabek.root_meaning: Related to embracing or holding closely

examples.hebrew: אֲנִי מְחַבֵּק אֶת הַיֶּלֶד כָּל בֹּקֶר.
examples.transliteration: Ani mechabék et ha-yéled kol bóker.
examples.translation: I hug the child every morning.

examples.hebrew: הֵם חִבְּקוּ זֹאת אֶת זֹאת אַחֲרֵי הַפְּגִישָׁה.
examples.transliteration: Hem chibkú zot et zot acharéi ha-pgishá.
examples.translation: They hugged each other after the meeting.

lechabek.notes: This verb is in binyan Piel (פִּעֵל), which often intensifies or specifies the root’s action. The root ח-ב-ק, with a guttural ח (chet), relates to embracing or holding closely. It’s a common expression of affection in modern Hebrew.

idioms.usage: הוּא חִבֵּק אֶת הָעֵץ כְּשֶׁטִּיֵּל בַּיַּעַר.
הִיא תָּמִיד מְחַבֶּקֶת בְּחֹם אֶת הַחֲבֵרִים שֶׁלָּהּ.

lenashek.root_meaning: Related to kissing or making contact with lips

examples.hebrew: אֲנִי מְנַשֵּׁק אֶת הַיֶּלֶד לִפְנֵי הַשֵּׁנָה.
examples.transliteration: Ani menashék et ha-yéled lifnéi ha-shéna.
examples.translation: I kiss the child before sleep.

examples.hebrew: הֵם נִשְּׁקוּ זֹאת אֶת זֹאת בַּסּוֹף הַטֶּקֶס.
examples.transliteration: Hem nishkú zot et zot ba-sóf ha-tékes.
examples.translation: They kissed each other at the end of the ceremony.

lenashek.notes: This verb is in binyan Piel (פִּעֵל), which often intensifies or specifies the root’s action. The root נ-ש-ק relates to kissing, commonly used for affectionate or greeting gestures in modern Hebrew.

idioms.usage: הוּא נִשֵּׁק אֶת הַיָּד שֶׁל הַסָּבָא מֵרֹב כָּבוֹד.
הִיא תָּמִיד מְנַשֶּׁקֶת בְּחֹם אֶת הַחֲבֵרִים שֶׁלָּהּ.

liga.root_meaning: Related to touching or making contact

examples.hebrew: אֲנִי נוֹגֵעַ בַּקִּיר כְּדֵי לִבְדּוֹק אִם הוּא רָטוֹב.
examples.transliteration: Ani nogéa ba-kir kedéi livdók im hu ratóv.
examples.translation: I touch the wall to check if it’s wet.
She touched his hand gently.

liga.notes: This verb is in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל), the simple active form. The root נ-ג-ע includes a guttural ע (ayin), affecting pronunciation (e.g., 'nagá' with a throaty sound). It’s used for physical contact, often with a sense of directness.
related_words: נוֹגֵעַ (nogéa) - toucher (m.), also 'concerning' in other contexts

idioms.usage: הוּא נָגַע בַּנְּקוּדָה כְּשֶׁדִּבֵּר עַל הַבְּעָיָה.
הַסִּפּוּר שֶׁלּוֹ נָגַע בְּלֵב כֻּלָּם.

nifal.note: Common in passive or emotional contexts

examples.translation: I throw the ball to the child.
They threw the trash into the bin.

lizrok.notes: This verb is in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל), the simple active form. The root ז-ר-ק is directly tied to throwing or casting, often implying a quick or forceful action. It’s regular with no guttural sounds.

idioms.usage: הוּא זָרַק אֶת הָרַעְיוֹן לָאַשְׁפָּה אַחֲרֵי הַוִּכּוּחַ.

idioms.translation: to throw the ball to someone (pass responsibility)
idioms.usage: הַמְּנַהֵל זָרַק אֶת הַכַּדּוּר לָעוֹבֵד הַחָדָשׁ.

nifal.note: Used in passive contexts

litpos.root_meaning: Related to catching, grasping, or seizing

examples.hebrew: אֲנִי תּוֹפֵס אֶת הַכַּדּוּר בְּיָד אַחַת.
examples.transliteration: Ani tofés et ha-kadúr be-yád achát.
examples.translation: I catch the ball with one hand.

examples.hebrew: הִיא תָּפְסָה אֶת הָרַעְיוֹן מַהֵר מְאוֹד.
examples.transliteration: Hi tafsá et ha-ra’ayón mahér me’ód.
examples.translation: She caught the idea very quickly.

litpos.notes: This verb is in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל), the simple active form. The root ת-פ-ס is tied to catching or seizing, used both physically (e.g., catching a ball) and figuratively (e.g., understanding). It’s regular with no guttural sounds.

idioms.usage: הוּא תָּפַס אֶת הַיּוֹם וְיָצָא לְטַיֵּל.

idioms.translation: to catch at this (take an opportunity)
idioms.usage: הִיא תָּפְסָה בַּזֹּאת וְהִתְחִילָה לַעֲבוֹד עַל הַפְּרוֹיֶקְט.

nifal.note: Common in passive contexts, e.g., being caught red-handed

examples.translation: I push the cart to the store.
They pushed the door with force.

lidchof.notes: This verb is in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל), the simple active form. The root ד-ח-ף includes a guttural ח (chet), affecting pronunciation (e.g., 'dacháf' with a throaty sound). It’s used for physical pushing or shoving.

idioms.usage: הוּא דָּחַף אֶת הָרַעְיוֹן שֶׁלּוֹ בִּפְגִישָׁה.
הִיא תָּמִיד דּוֹחֶפֶת אֶת הַדְּבָרִים קָדִימָה.

nifal.note: Common in passive contexts

examples.translation: I pull the rope with force.
She pulled the curtain to the side.

limshoch.notes: This verb is in binyan Pa'al (פָּעַל), the simple active form. The root מ-ש-ך has no guttural sounds, making it straightforward to conjugate. It’s used for physical pulling or dragging, and occasionally figuratively (e.g., delaying).

idioms.usage: הוּא מָשַׁךְ בַּזֹּאת כְּדֵי לֹא לְהַחְלִיט מַהֵר.
הִיא מוֹשֶׁכֶת אֶת הַזְּמַן כְּדֵי לֹא לְדַבֵּר עִם הַבֹּס.

nifal.note: Often used for duration (e.g., 'it dragged on')

lechakor.root_meaning: Related to investigating, researching, or exploring

examples.hebrew: אֲנִי מְחַקֵּר אֶת הַתְּאוּנָה שֶׁקָּרְתָה אֶתְמוֹל.
examples.transliteration: Ani mechakér et ha-te’uná she-kartá etmól.
examples.translation: I am investigating the accident that happened yesterday.

examples.hebrew: הֵם חִקְּרוּ אֶת הַנּוֹשֵׂא בְּמֶשֶׁךְ שָׁנָה.
examples.transliteration: Hem chikrú et ha-nosé bémeshech shaná.
examples.translation: They investigated the topic for a year.

lechakor.notes: This verb is in binyan Piel (פִּעֵל), which often intensifies or specifies the root’s action. The root ח-ק-ר, with a guttural ח (chet), relates to investigation or research, commonly used in formal or intellectual contexts. It can also mean 'to explore' depending on context.

idioms.usage: הַשּׁוֹטֵר חִקֵּר עַד הַסּוֹף אֶת הַפְּשָׁעִים.
הַצּוֹוֵת מְחַקֵּר בְּעֹמֶק אֶת הַתֹּפָעָה.

examples.hebrew: אֲנִי מִתְמַהְמֵהַּ כִּי אֵין לִי חֵשֶׁק לַעֲבוֹד.
examples.transliteration: Ani mitmahméa ki ein li chéshek la’avód.
examples.translation: I procrastinate because I don’t feel like working.

examples.hebrew: הֵם הִתְמַהְמְהוּ עִם הַהַחְלָטָה עַד הָרֶגַע הָאַחֲרוֹן.
examples.transliteration: Hem hitmahmhú im ha-hachlatá ad ha-réga ha-achazón.
examples.translation: They procrastinated with the decision until the last moment.

lehitmahmea.notes: This verb is in binyan Hitpael (הִתְפַּעֵל), which often implies reflexive or introspective action. The root מ-ה-מ, with a guttural ה (he), relates to delay or hesitation. It’s less common and more formal than alternatives like לִדְחוֹת (lidchót, 'to postpone'), making it advanced.

idioms.usage: הוּא תָּמִיד מִתְמַהְמֵהַּ עַל הַדֶּרֶךְ לָעֲבוֹדָה.
הִיא מִתְמַהְמַהַּת בְּלִי סוֹף עִם הַמִּשְׂחָקִים שֶׁלָּהּ.

lehalchish.root_meaning: Related to whispering or speaking softly

examples.hebrew: הַמּוֹרֶה מַלְחִישׁ אֶת הַתַּלְמִידִים כְּדֵי לֹא לְהַפְרִיעַ.
examples.transliteration: Ha-moré malchísh et ha-talmidím kedéi lo lehafría.
examples.translation: The teacher causes the students to whisper so as not to disturb.

examples.hebrew: הִיא הִלְחִישָׁה לִי סוֹד בְּקוֹל רָךְ.
examples.transliteration: Hi hilchísha li sód be-kól rakh.
examples.translation: She whispered a secret to me softly (caused me to hear it whispered).

lehalchish.notes: This verb is in binyan Hifil (הִפְעִיל), which typically conveys causation. The root ל-ח-ש, with a guttural ח (chet), relates to whispering, and in Hifil, it means 'to cause to whisper' or sometimes 'to whisper softly' in a poetic sense. It’s less common than לִלְחוֹשׁ (lidchóf, Pa'al), making it advanced.
related_words: מַלְחִישׁ (malchísh) - one who causes to whisper (m.)
הַלְחָשָׁה (halchashá) - act of causing to whisper

idioms.usage: הוּא הִלְחִישׁ לְאֹזְנֵנוּ אֶת הַתָּכְנִית הַסּוֹדִית.
הִיא מַלְחִישָׁה בְּרַכּוּת כְּדֵי לֹא לְהָעִיר אֶת הַתִּינוֹק.

nifal.note: Passive, rare

leharim.root_meaning: Related to raising, lifting, or height

examples.translation: I lift the heavy bag.
They raised the flag at the ceremony.

leharim.notes: This verb is in binyan Hifil (הִפְעִיל), which often conveys causation or an active raising action. The root ר-ו-מ (r-u-m) relates to height or elevation, with the ו (vav) typically dropping in conjugation. It’s used both literally (lifting objects) and figuratively (raising spirits, voices).

idioms.usage: הַמְּאַמֵּן הֵרִים אֶת הַמּוֹרָל שֶׁל הַקְּבוּצָה.
הֵם הֵרִימוּ יָדַיִם לְתַמּוֹךְ בַּהַצָּעָה.

nifal.note: Common in passive or natural rising contexts

examples.translation: The letters were corresponded between the friends.
The messages are corresponded precisely.

kutav.notes: Regular verb in binyan Pual (פֻּעַל), the passive counterpart to Piel (כִּתֵּב - 'to correspond'). Used in contexts of written correspondence, though less common in modern Hebrew.

idioms.usage: הַהוֹדָעָה מְכֻתֶּבֶת בְּרוּר לְכֻלָּם.

shulach.root_meaning: Related to sending, releasing, or extending

examples.hebrew: הַחֲיָלִים שֻׁלְּחוּ לַגְּבוּל בְּדֹחַף עַל יְדֵי הַמְּפַקֵּד.
examples.transliteration: Ha-chayalím shulchú la-gvúl be-dóchaf al yedéi ha-mefakéd.
examples.translation: The soldiers were dispatched to the border urgently by the commander.
The letters are dispatched every evening.

examples.hebrew: הַצְּיּוּד יְשֻׁלַּח לַמַּחְסָן אִם יִהְיֶה צֹרֶךְ.
examples.transliteration: Ha-tziyúd yeshulách la-machsán im yihyé tzórek.
examples.translation: The equipment will be dispatched to the warehouse if there’s a need.

shulach.notes: Pu'al is the passive form of Pi'el, turning 'to dispatch' into 'to be dispatched'. It’s rare in modern spoken Hebrew, appearing mostly in formal or written contexts to emphasize an intensive or deliberate act of being sent, overlapping with Nif'al and Huf'al ('to be sent') but with a stronger sense of dispatch.

idioms.usage: הַצָּוֶת מְשֻׁלָּח לְרַחוֹק לְבַדֹּק אֶת הַשֵּׁטַח. (The team is dispatched far away to check the area.)

examples.hebrew: הם כִּתְּבוּ זֶה עִם זֶה בְּדֶרֶךְ קְבָעִית.
examples.transliteration: Hem kitvú zeh im zeh bederekh kevaít.
examples.translation: They corresponded with each other regularly.
I corresponded with him by email.

kitev_piel.notes: Regular verb in binyan Piel (פִּעֵל). The root כ.ת.ב is associated with writing and communication, and in Piel, it implies an intensive or repeated action like corresponding or spelling out clearly.

idioms.usage: הוּא כִּתֵּב אֶת הַמְּסָר בְּצוֹרָה מְבוּטָחָה.
אֲנִי כִּתֵּב אִתּוֹ לְתַקּוּפוֹת בְּשָׁנָה.

nikra_nifal.root_meaning: Related to reading, calling, or summoning

examples.translation: The book is read all over the world.
He is called Samson.

nikra_nifal.notes: Regular verb in binyan Nifal (נִפְעַל). The root ק.ר.א is associated with reading and calling, and in Nifal, it indicates a passive or reflexive action, such as being read or called.

idioms.translation: to be called by a good name
idioms.usage: הוּא נִקְרָא לְשֵׁם טוֹב בְּכָל הָעִיר.
הַתַּלְמִיד נִקְרָא לַמִּשְׁמָע בְּכִתָּה.

examples.translation: The book was written last year.
The letters are written every day.
The report will be written by the end of the month.

nikhtav.notes: Nif'al is the passive form of Pa'al, used to indicate that the subject is being acted upon. For the root כ.ת.ב, it means 'to be written'. In modern Hebrew, feminine plural forms in the future tense may be less commonly used, with masculine plural forms often substituted.

idioms.usage: הָאַהֲבָה שֶׁלָּהֶם נִכְתְּבָה בַּכּוֹכָבִים. (Their love was written in the stars.)

examples.translation: They corresponded for many years.

examples.hebrew: היא מִתְכַּתֶּבֶת עם חברים מֵעַבְרֵי הַיָּם.
examples.transliteration: Hi mitkatévet im chaverim me'avrei ha-yam.
examples.translation: She corresponds with friends from overseas.
We will correspond by email after the meeting.

hitkatev.notes: Hitpa'el is often used for reflexive or reciprocal actions. For the root כ.ת.ב, it means 'to correspond with someone' or 'to exchange letters', implying mutual communication. In modern Hebrew, feminine plural forms in the future and imperative may be less commonly used, with masculine plural forms often substituted.
similar_verbs: הִתְרַאֵה (to meet, to see each other)

idioms.usage: הם הִתְכַּתְּבוּ בְּעִנְיָנֵי עֲבוֹדָה בְּמֶשֶׁךְ הַפְּרוֹיֶקְט. (They corresponded about work matters throughout the project.)

examples.translation: The teacher dictated a letter to the students.
The manager dictates instructions to the secretary.

examples.hebrew: אני אַכְתִּיב לָךְ אֶת הַתּוֹכְנִית מָחָר.
examples.transliteration: Ani aktív lach et ha-tochnit machar.
examples.translation: I will dictate the plan to you tomorrow.

hiktiv.notes: Hif'il is the causative form of Pa'al, meaning 'to cause something to be written'. For the root כ.ת.ב, it translates to 'to dictate'. In modern Hebrew, feminine plural forms in the future and imperative may be less commonly used, with masculine plural forms often substituted.

idioms.usage: הַצָּוֶת הִכְתִּיב אֶת הַקְּצָב לַפְּרוֹיֶקְט. (The team dictated the pace for the project.)

examples.translation: The letter was dictated by the manager.
The instructions are dictated to all the employees.
The report will be dictated according to the precise plan.

hukhtav.notes: Huf'al is the passive form of Hif'il, indicating that the subject is the recipient of the action of dictation. It is less commonly used in modern spoken Hebrew but appears in formal or written contexts. Feminine plural forms in the future tense may be replaced by masculine plural forms in casual speech.
similar_verbs: הֻשְׁמַע (to be played, to be made heard)

idioms.usage: הַחֲלָטוֹת הֻכְתְּבוּ מִלְּמַעְלָה עַל יְדֵי הַהַנְהָלָה. (The decisions were dictated from above by the management.)

nishmar.root_meaning: Related to guarding, keeping, or observing

examples.hebrew: הַבַּיִת נִשְׁמַר עַל יְדֵי שׁוֹמְרִים בַּלַּיְלָה.
examples.transliteration: Ha-báyit nishmár al yedei shomrím ba-láyla.
examples.translation: The house was guarded by guards at night.
I beware of dangers on the road.
The secret will be kept forever.

nishmar.notes: Nif'al serves as the passive of Pa'al ('to be guarded') or a reflexive sense ('to beware'). The reflexive meaning 'to beware' is particularly common in modern Hebrew, often used with 'מִפְּנֵי' (mipnei, 'from') to indicate caution.

idioms.usage: הוא נִשְׁמַר לְנַפְשׁוֹ בְּסִבּוּב בָּעִיר הַמּוּזְנַחַת. (He watched out for himself while wandering in the neglected city.)

shimer.root_meaning: Related to guarding, keeping, or observing

examples.translation: She preserved the family traditions.

examples.hebrew: הַצָּוֶת מְשַׁמֵּר אֶת הַצִּיּוּד בְּמַצָּב טוֹב.
examples.transliteration: Ha-tzavét meshamér et ha-tziyúd be-matzáv tov.
examples.translation: The team maintains the equipment in good condition.
I will preserve these memories forever.

shimer.notes: Pi'el often intensifies the action of Pa'al. For שׁ.מ.ר, it shifts from 'to guard' to 'to preserve' or 'to maintain', emphasizing active care or upkeep. It’s commonly used for preserving intangible things like traditions or maintaining physical objects.

idioms.usage: הם שִׁמְּרוּ עַל הַטָּהֳרָה שֶׁל הַמָּקוֹם הַקָּדוֹשׁ. (They preserved the purity of the holy place.)

shumar.root_meaning: Related to guarding, keeping, or observing

examples.translation: The tradition was preserved over generations.
The equipment is preserved under special conditions.
These memories will be preserved forever.

shumar.notes: Pu'al is the passive form of Pi'el, turning 'to preserve' into 'to be preserved'. It is less common in everyday speech but appears in formal or written contexts, often related to preservation of traditions, objects, or states.

idioms.usage: הַיֶּלֶד שֶׁלָּהֶם מְשֻׁמָּר בְּצֶמֶר גֶּפֶן. (Their child is overprotected.)

hitshamer.root_meaning: Related to guarding, keeping, or observing

examples.translation: He protected himself from the danger on the road.

examples.hebrew: אני מִתְשַׁמֶּרֶת עַל יְדֵי לְבִישַׁת מַסֵּכָה.
examples.transliteration: Ani mitshaméret al yedei levishát masécha.
examples.translation: I protect myself by wearing a mask.
We will take care during the hike in the forest.

hitshamer.notes: Hitpa'el often indicates reflexive or reciprocal action. For שׁ.מ.ר, it means 'to protect oneself' or 'to take care', often used with 'מִפְּנֵי' (mipnei, 'from') to specify what one is guarding against. It’s moderately common in modern Hebrew, especially in safety contexts.

idioms.usage: בְּמָקוֹם כָּזֶה, כֻּלָּם מִתְשַׁמְּרִים לְעַצְמָם. (In a place like this, everyone looks out for themselves.)

hashmir.root_meaning: Related to guarding, keeping, or observing

examples.hebrew: היא הִשְׁמִירָה לִי אֶת הַסּוֹד שֶׁלָּהּ.
examples.transliteration: Hi hashmíra li et ha-sod sheláh.
examples.translation: She entrusted her secret to me.

examples.hebrew: הַמְּנַהֵל מַשְׁמִיר אֶת הַמִּשְׂרָד לַעוֹבֵד הַחָדָשׁ.
examples.transliteration: Ha-menahél mashmír et ha-misrad la-ovéd ha-chadásh.
examples.translation: The manager entrusts the office to the new employee.

examples.hebrew: אַשְׁמִיר לָךְ אֶת הַמַּפְתֵּחַ לְיּוֹם אֶחָד.
examples.transliteration: Ashmír lach et ha-maftéach le-yom echád.
examples.translation: I will entrust the key to you for one day.

hashmir.notes: Hif'il is the causative form of Pa'al, meaning 'to cause to guard' or 'to entrust'. For שׁ.מ.ר, it often implies assigning someone to guard or entrusting something to their care. In modern Hebrew, feminine plural forms in the future and imperative may be less common, with masculine plural forms sometimes used instead.

idioms.usage: הִשְׁמַרְנוּ אֶת הַפְּרוֹיֶקְט בְּיָדֵי נֶאֱמָן. (We entrusted the project into faithful hands.)

hushmar.root_meaning: Related to guarding, keeping, or observing

examples.hebrew: הַסּוֹד הֻשְׁמַר לִי עַל יְדֵי חֲבֵרָה.
examples.transliteration: Ha-sod hushmár li al yedei chaverá.
examples.translation: The secret was entrusted to me by a friend.
The office is entrusted to the new employee.
The key will be entrusted to you for one day.

hushmar.notes: Huf'al is the passive form of Hif'il, turning 'to entrust' into 'to be entrusted' or 'to be kept'. It is rare in modern spoken Hebrew but appears in formal or written contexts, often implying something is placed under someone’s care or custody.
similar_verbs: הֻפְקַד (to be deposited, to be entrusted)

idioms.usage: הַפְּרוֹיֶקְט מֻשְׁמָר בְּיָדֵי הַצָּוֶת הַזֶּה. (The project is kept in the hands of this team.)

nilmad.root_meaning: Related to learning, studying, or teaching

examples.translation: This lesson was learned at school.

examples.hebrew: עִבְרִית נִלְמֶדֶת בְּקֹלֹת עַל יְדֵי תַּלְמִידִים רַבִּים.
examples.transliteration: Ivrít nilmédet be-kólot al yedei talmidím rabím.
examples.translation: Hebrew is learned easily by many students.
This skill will be learned during the course.

nilmad.notes: Nif'al serves as the passive of Pa'al ('to be learned') and can also imply 'to be taught' in some contexts, though Pi'el ('to teach') is more common for active teaching. It’s moderately frequent in educational settings, especially when discussing subjects or skills being acquired passively.

idioms.usage: הַשִּׁעוּר הַזֶּה נִלְמַד בְּדֶרֶךְ הַקָּשָׁה עַל יְדֵי כֻּלָּם. (This lesson was learned the hard way by everyone.)

lumad.root_meaning: Related to learning, studying, or teaching

examples.hebrew: עִבְרִית לֻמְּדָה בְּבֵית הַסֵּפֶר עַל יְדֵי הַמּוֹרָה.
examples.transliteration: Ivrít lumdá be-véit ha-séfer al yedei ha-móra.
examples.translation: Hebrew was taught at school by the teacher.
This skill is taught in special courses.
These lessons will be taught during the year.

lumad.notes: Pu'al is the passive form of Pi'el, turning 'to teach' into 'to be taught'. It is less common in everyday spoken Hebrew but appears in formal or educational contexts, emphasizing the intensive teaching process received by the subject. The adjective 'מְלֻמָּד' (melumad, 'learned') is more frequently used than the verb itself.

idioms.usage: הַלֶּקַח הַזֶּה לֻמַּד בְּיָגוֹן רַב. (This lesson was taught through great sorrow.)

hitlamad.root_meaning: Related to learning, studying, or teaching

examples.hebrew: הוא הִתְלַמֵּד לְנַגֵּן עַל גִּיטָרָה לְבַד.
examples.transliteration: Hu hitlaméd lenagén al gitára levád.
examples.translation: He trained himself to play the guitar alone.
I am becoming accustomed to managing in a new place.
We will train ourselves to dance before the wedding.

hitlamad.notes: Hitpa'el indicates reflexive or intensive action. For ל.מ.ד, it means 'to train oneself' or 'to become accustomed', often implying self-directed learning or adaptation. It’s moderately common in modern Hebrew, especially in contexts of self-improvement or habit formation.

idioms.translation: to get trained for the job
idioms.usage: הִתְלַמַּדְתִּי לַעֲבוֹדָה תּוֹךְ חֹדֶשׁ אֶחָד. (I got trained for the job within one month.)

halmid.root_meaning: Related to learning, studying, or teaching

examples.hebrew: הַמּוֹרָה הִלְמִידָה אֶת הַתַּלְמִידִים לִקְרֹא עִבְרִית.
examples.transliteration: Ha-móra halmída et ha-talmidím likró ivrít.
examples.translation: The teacher trained the students to read Hebrew.

examples.hebrew: הַמְּאַמֵּן מַלְמִיד אֶת הַצָּוֶת לַעֲבוֹד בְּיַחַד.
examples.transliteration: Ha-me’amén malmíd et ha-tzavét la’avód be-yáchad.
examples.translation: The coach trains the team to work together.

examples.hebrew: אַלְמִיד אֶת הַיֶּלֶד לִרְקֹד לִפְנֵי הַמּוֹעֵד.
examples.transliteration: Almíd et ha-yéled lirkód lifnéi ha-mo’éd.
examples.translation: I will train the child to dance before the deadline.

halmid.notes: Hif'il is the causative form of Pa'al, shifting 'to learn' to 'to cause to learn' or 'to train'. For ל.מ.ד, it often implies actively training or enabling someone to acquire a skill or knowledge. While less common than Pi'el ('to teach'), it’s used in contexts emphasizing structured training or causation.

idioms.translation: to train to know (to instill knowledge)
idioms.usage: הִלְמַדְתִּי אוֹתוֹ לְדַעַת אֵיךְ לִפְתֹּר בְּעָיוֹת. (I trained him to know how to solve problems.)

hulmad.root_meaning: Related to learning, studying, or teaching

examples.hebrew: הַתַּלְמִידִים הֻלְמְדוּ לִקְרֹא עַל יְדֵי הַמּוֹרָה.
examples.transliteration: Ha-talmidím hulmdú likró al yedei ha-móra.
examples.translation: The students were trained to read by the teacher.
The team is trained to work under pressure.
The child will be trained to dance during the summer.

hulmad.notes: Huf'al is the passive form of Hif'il, turning 'to train' into 'to be trained' or 'to be made to learn'. It is rare in modern spoken Hebrew, appearing mostly in formal or written contexts to describe a training process imposed on the subject.

idioms.usage: הַצָּוֶת הַזֶּה מֻלְמָד לְטוֹבָה לְכָל מִשִּׂימָה. (This team is well-prepared for any task.)

kira.root_meaning: Related to reading, calling, or reciting

examples.hebrew: הַתַּלְמִיד קִרֵּא אֶת הַשִּׁיר בְּקוֹל רָם.
examples.transliteration: Ha-talmíd kiré et ha-shir be-kól ram.
examples.translation: The student recited the poem aloud.
The teacher summons the students to the classroom.
I will recite the prayer during the ceremony.

kira.notes: Pi'el intensifies the Pa'al meaning ('to read') into 'to recite' or 'to summon', often implying a formal or performative reading aloud or calling someone. It’s moderately common in contexts like education, liturgy, or summoning people.

idioms.usage: הוא קִרֵּא בְּקוֹל אֶת הַמִּכְתָּב לְפָנֵי כֻּלָּם. (He recited the letter aloud in front of everyone.)

kura.root_meaning: Related to reading, calling, or reciting

examples.translation: The poem was recited aloud at the ceremony.
The students are summoned to the classroom every morning.
The prayer will be recited during the celebration.

kura.notes: Pu'al is the passive form of Pi'el, turning 'to recite' or 'to summon' into 'to be recited' or 'to be summoned'. It is less common in modern spoken Hebrew, appearing mostly in formal, liturgical, or written contexts, often overlapping with Nif'al ('to be read'), but with a more intensive or performative connotation.

idioms.usage: הַסִּפּוּרִים הָאֵלֶּה מְקֻרָּאִים בְּפֶה מִדּוֹר לְדוֹר. (These stories are recited by mouth from generation to generation.)

hitkara.root_meaning: Related to reading, calling, or reciting

examples.hebrew: הוא הִתְקַרֵּא בְּשֵׁם חָדָשׁ לְאַחַר הַמַּעֲבָר.
examples.transliteration: Hu hitkaré be-shém chadásh le’achár ha-ma’avár.
examples.translation: He called himself by a new name after the move.
The students are summoned to the office every day.
I will be summoned to a meeting if there’s a need.

hitkara.notes: Hitpa'el indicates reflexive or intensive action. For ק.ר.א, it means 'to call oneself' (reflexive, e.g., adopting a name) or 'to be summoned' (passive-intensive), often overlapping with Nif'al ('to be called') but with a more active sense of self-naming or formal summoning. It’s moderately common in modern Hebrew, especially in naming or summoning contexts.

idioms.translation: to call oneself by a name
idioms.usage: הִתְקַרֵּא בְּשֵׁם 'מֹשֶׁה' לְאַחַר הַטִּיּוּל בְּמִצְרַיִם. (He called himself 'Moshe' after the trip to Egypt.)

hukra.root_meaning: Related to reading, calling, or reciting

examples.hebrew: הַתַּלְמִיד הֻקְרַא לִקְרֹא אֶת הַטֶּקְסְט בְּפְנֵי הַכִּתָּה.
examples.transliteration: Ha-talmíd hukrá likró et ha-tékst be-fnéi ha-kitá.
examples.translation: The student was made to read the text in front of the class.
Everyone is invited to the birthday party.

examples.hebrew: הַחֲבֵרִים יֻקְרְאוּ לְטֶקֶס הַסִּיּוּם בְּסוֹף הַשָּׁנָה.
examples.transliteration: Ha-chaverím yukr’ú le-tékes ha-siyúm be-sóf ha-shaná.
examples.translation: The friends will be invited to the graduation ceremony at the end of the year.

hukra.notes: Huf'al is the passive form of Hif'il, turning 'to invite' or 'to cause to read' into 'to be invited' or 'to be made to read'. It’s rare in modern spoken Hebrew, appearing mostly in formal or written contexts, such as invitations or educational settings where someone is compelled to read.

idioms.usage: הוּא הֻקְרָא לְשֵׁם לְדַבֵּר בְּאֵירוּעַ הַזֶּה. (He was specially invited to speak at this event.)

hakria.root_meaning: Related to reading, calling, or reciting

examples.hebrew: הִקְרֵאתִי אֶת הַחֲבֵרִים לְמִסִּבַּת הַיּוֹם הֻלֶּדֶת.
examples.transliteration: Hikréti et ha-chaverím le-misíbat ha-yom hulédet.
examples.translation: I invited the friends to the birthday party.

examples.hebrew: הַמּוֹרֶה מַקְרִיא אֶת הַתַּלְמִיד לִקְרֹא אֶת הַשִּׁיר.
examples.transliteration: Ha-moré makría et ha-talmíd likró et ha-shir.
examples.translation: The teacher causes the student to read the poem.

examples.hebrew: נַקְרִיא אֶת הַמִּשְׁפָּחָה לַחֲגִיגָה בְּיוֹם שִׁשִּׁי.
examples.transliteration: Nakría et ha-mishpachá la-chagigá be-yom shishí.
examples.translation: We will invite the family to the celebration on Friday.

hakria.notes: Hif'il is the causative form of Pa'al, shifting 'to read' or 'to call' into 'to cause to read' or 'to invite'. In modern Hebrew, 'to invite' is the dominant usage, while 'to cause to read' appears in educational contexts. It’s moderately common, particularly for social or formal invitations.

idioms.translation: invited for the sake of appearance (token invitation)
idioms.usage: הִקְרִיאוּ אוֹתוֹ לְשֵׁם תּוֹפָעָה בִּלְבַד. (They invited him just for show.)

nishma.root_meaning: Related to hearing, listening, or announcing

examples.translation: His voice was heard from afar.
This (f.) is heard throughout the room.
Our complaints will be heard if we make an effort.

nishma.notes: Nif'al serves as the passive of Pa'al ('to hear'), meaning 'to be heard'. It’s commonly used in modern Hebrew to describe sounds or voices being audible, and it’s frequent in both spoken and written contexts.

idioms.usage: הַסִּפּוּר שֶׁלּוֹ נִשְׁמַע כְּמוֹ אֱמֶת. (His story sounds like the truth.)

shimea.root_meaning: Related to hearing, listening, or announcing

examples.translation: The teacher announced the results to the students.
The principal announces a change in the schedule.
I will announce the news to everyone tomorrow.

shimea.notes: Pi'el intensifies the Pa'al meaning ('to hear') into 'to announce' or 'to proclaim', focusing on actively making something audible or known. It’s moderately common in formal or educational contexts in modern Hebrew, though Hif'il ('to cause to hear') is more frequent for broadcasting sound.

idioms.usage: הִיא שִׁמְּעָה בְּקוֹל רָם עַל הַנִּצָּחוֹן. (She announced the victory loudly.)

shuma.root_meaning: Related to hearing, listening, or announcing

examples.hebrew: הַתּוֹצָאוֹת שֻׁמְּעוּ בְּרַם־קוֹל עַל יְדֵי הַמּוֹרֶה.
examples.transliteration: Ha-totza’ót shum’ú be-ram-kól al yedei ha-móre.
examples.translation: The results were announced over the loudspeaker by the teacher.
The news is announced every evening.
The changes will be announced to everyone at the next meeting.

shuma.notes: Pu'al is the passive form of Pi'el, turning 'to announce' into 'to be announced'. It’s less common in modern spoken Hebrew, appearing mostly in formal or written contexts, such as official announcements or broadcasts. Hif'il ('to cause to hear') and its passive Huf'al are more frequent for similar meanings.

idioms.usage: הַחֲדָשׁוֹת הָאֵלֶּה מְשֻׁמָּעוֹת לְרַבִּים בְּרַדְיוֹ. (This news is announced to the masses on the radio.)

hitshamea.root_meaning: Related to hearing, listening, or announcing

examples.translation: I listened attentively to the bell’s ringing with great precision.

examples.hebrew: הוּא מִתְשַׁמֵּעַ לְכָל מִלָּה שֶׁאֲנִי אוֹמֵר.
examples.transliteration: Hu mitshamé’a le-chól milá she-aní omér.
examples.translation: He listens attentively to every word I say.
We will listen attentively to the lecture if we want to understand.

hitshamea.notes: Hitpa'el indicates reflexive or intensive action. For שׁ.מ.ע, it means 'to listen attentively' (actively focusing on hearing) or 'to make oneself heard' (less common). It’s moderately frequent in modern Hebrew, especially in contexts requiring careful listening, like education or instructions.

idioms.translation: to listen to the heart’s voice
idioms.usage: הִתְשַׁמַּעְתִּי לְקוֹל הַלֵּב וְהֶחְלַטְתִּי לָלֶכֶת. (I listened to my heart and decided to go.)

hashmia.root_meaning: Related to hearing, listening, or announcing

examples.translation: I caused the friends to hear the song at the party (played it for them).
The teacher informs the students of the news.
I will inform everyone of the results tomorrow.

hashmia.notes: Hif'il is the causative form of Pa'al, shifting 'to hear' into 'to cause to hear' or 'to inform'. In modern Hebrew, it’s widely used for both making sounds audible (e.g., playing music) and sharing information, making it one of the most frequent forms of this root.

idioms.usage: הוּא הִשְׁמִיעַ קוֹלוֹ בְּעֵת הַדִּיּוּן. (He expressed himself during the discussion.)

hushma.root_meaning: Related to hearing, listening, or announcing

examples.translation: The song was made to be heard by us through the radio.
The students are informed about the schedule changes.
The news will be informed to everyone in an hour.

hushma.notes: Huf'al is the passive form of Hif'il, turning 'to cause to hear' or 'to inform' into 'to be made to hear' or 'to be informed'. It’s rare in modern spoken Hebrew, appearing mostly in formal or written contexts, such as broadcasts or official notifications.

idioms.usage: הַהַחְלָטָה הֻשְׁמְעָה לְרַבִּים בִּזְמַן אֲמִתִּי. (The decision was informed to the masses in real time.)

davar.root_meaning: Related to speaking, talking, or things

examples.translation: I spoke with the teacher about the lesson.
He speaks Hebrew fluently.
I will speak with you tomorrow about the plan.

davar.notes: Pa'al for ד.ב.ר means 'to speak' in a general sense, often used with direct objects or prepositions (e.g., 'with someone'). While Pi'el ( diber - 'to speak') is more common in modern Hebrew for formal or prolonged speech, Pa'al remains a simpler, foundational form, especially in biblical Hebrew or poetic contexts.

idioms.usage: הוּא דָּבַר מִלֵּב וְרִגֵּשׁ אֶת כֻּלָּם. (He spoke from the heart and moved everyone.)

nidbar.root_meaning: Related to speaking, talking, or things

examples.hebrew: הַמִּלּוֹת הָאֵלֶּה נִדְבְּרוּ בְּשֵׁקֶט עַל יְדֵי הַיֶּלֶד.
examples.transliteration: Ha-milót ha-éle nidberú be-shéket al yedéi ha-yéled.
examples.translation: These words were spoken quietly by the child.
Hebrew is spoken throughout the country.

examples.hebrew: הַסִּפּוּר יִדָּבֵר בְּפִי כֻּלָּם אִם נְסַפֵּר אוֹתוֹ.
examples.transliteration: Ha-sipúr yidabér be-fí kulám im nesapér otó.
examples.translation: The story will be spoken by everyone if we tell it.

nidbar.notes: Nif'al is the passive form of Pa'al, turning 'to speak' into 'to be spoken'. It’s less common in modern Hebrew, where Pi'el ('to speak') dominates, but it appears in formal or literary contexts to describe languages or words being uttered.

idioms.usage: הַסִּפּוּר הַזֶּה נִדְבַּר בְּפִי הָעָם שָׁנִים רַבּוֹת. (This story was spoken by the people for many years.)

dubar.root_meaning: Related to speaking, talking, or things

examples.hebrew: הַנָּאוּם דֻּבַּר בְּקוֹל רָם עַל יְדֵי הַמַּנְהִיג.
examples.transliteration: Ha-ne’úm dubár be-kól ram al yedéi ha-manhíg.
examples.translation: The speech was spoken loudly by the leader.
Secrets are spoken in whispers among the friends.
The news will be spoken on the radio in the next hour.

dubar.notes: Pu'al is the passive form of Pi'el, turning 'to speak' into 'to be spoken'. It’s rare in modern spoken Hebrew, appearing mostly in formal or written contexts to emphasize the intensive act of speech being received, often overlapping with Nif'al ('to be spoken') but with a stronger sense of deliberate utterance.

idioms.usage: הַסִּפּוּר הַזֶּה מְדֻבָּר בְּפִי כֹּל בָּעִיר. (This story is spoken by all in the city.)

hitdaber.root_meaning: Related to speaking, talking, or things

examples.translation: I conversed with him about the plan for tomorrow.

examples.hebrew: הַנּוֹשֵׂא מִתְדַּבֵּר בֵּין הַחֲבֵרִים בְּכָל יוֹם.
examples.transliteration: Ha-nosé mitdabér béin ha-chaverím be-chól yom.
examples.translation: The topic is discussed among the friends every day.

examples.hebrew: נִתְדַּבֵּר בְּטֵלֵפוֹן אִם לֹא נוּכַל לְהִפָּגֵשׁ.
examples.transliteration: Nitdabér be-télefon im lo nuchál lehipagésh.
examples.translation: We will converse by phone if we can’t meet.

hitdaber.notes: Hitpa'el indicates reflexive or reciprocal action. For ד.ב.ר, it means 'to converse' (reciprocal speech with someone) or 'to be discussed' (intensive passive). It’s moderately common in modern Hebrew, especially for informal conversations or topics under discussion, complementing Pi'el’s more formal 'to speak'.

idioms.translation: to converse with an open heart
idioms.usage: הִתְדַּבַּרְנוּ בְּלֵב פָּתוּחַ וְהִגַּעְנוּ לְהַסְכָּמָה. (We conversed with open hearts and reached an agreement.)

hadbir.root_meaning: Related to speaking, talking, or things

examples.translation: I caused the child to speak in front (of others).
The teacher dictates the letter to the secretary.

examples.hebrew: אַדְבִּיר אֶת הַנָּאוּם לְךָ אִם תִּרְצֶה לִכְתֹּב.
examples.transliteration: Adbír et ha-ne’úm lechá im tirtzé lichtóv.
examples.translation: I will dictate the speech to you if you want to write it.

hadbir.notes: Hif'il is the causative form of Pa'al, shifting 'to speak' into 'to cause to speak' or 'to dictate'. In modern Hebrew, 'to dictate' is the more common usage, especially in contexts like writing or formal instruction, while 'to cause to speak' appears less frequently. It’s moderately used, particularly in educational or administrative settings.

idioms.usage: הוּא הִדְבִּיר דְּבָרִים לְפִי סֵדֶר לְהַבְטִיחַ הַבָּנָה. (He dictated things in order to ensure understanding.)

hudbar.root_meaning: Related to speaking, talking, or things

examples.hebrew: הַמִּכְתָּב הֻדְבַּר לַמַּזְכִּירָה עַל יְדֵי הַמּוֹרֶה.
examples.transliteration: Ha-michtáv hudbár la-mazkirá al yedéi ha-moré.
examples.translation: The letter was dictated to the secretary by the teacher.

examples.hebrew: הַיְלָדִים מֻדְבָּרִים לְדַבֵּר בְּקוֹל רָם בַּכִּתָּה.
examples.transliteration: Ha-yeladím mudbarím le-dabér be-kól ram ba-kitá.
examples.translation: The children are made to speak loudly in the class.
The speech will be dictated to everyone in an hour.

hudbar.notes: Huf'al is the passive form of Hif'il, turning 'to cause to speak' or 'to dictate' into 'to be made to speak' or 'to be dictated'. It’s rare in modern spoken Hebrew, appearing mostly in formal or written contexts, such as dictation processes or enforced speech.

idioms.usage: הַדְּבָרִים הֻדְבְּרוּ לְפִי הַחֹק בְּבֵית הַמִּשְׁפָּט. (The matters were dictated by the law in court.)

nishlach.root_meaning: Related to sending, releasing, or extending

examples.translation: The letter was sent to my house by registered mail.
The soldiers are sent to battle every day.
The news will be sent to everyone in an hour.

nishlach.notes: Nif'al is the passive form of Pa'al, turning 'to send' into 'to be sent'. It’s frequently used in modern Hebrew for simple passive actions like mail or people being sent, overlapping with Huf'al ('to be sent', your entry) but with a less causative nuance.

idioms.usage: הַצָּוֶת נִשְׁלַח בְּרֹאשׁ לְבַדֹּק אֶת הַשֵּׁטַח. (The team was sent ahead to check the area.)

shileach.root_meaning: Related to sending, releasing, or extending

examples.translation: I dispatched the soldiers to battle urgently.

examples.hebrew: הַמַּנְהֵל מְשַׁלֵּחַ אֶת הַמִּכְתָּבִים בְּכָל יוֹם.
examples.transliteration: Ha-manhél meshaléach et ha-michtavím be-chól yom.
examples.translation: The manager dispatches the letters every day.
I will dispatch the news to everyone tomorrow.

shileach.notes: Pi'el intensifies the Pa'al meaning ('to send') into 'to dispatch' or 'to send forth', implying a more deliberate or forceful act of sending. It’s moderately common in modern Hebrew, often used for official or urgent sending, contrasting with Pa'al’s simpler usage.

idioms.usage: הוּא שִׁלֵּחַ אֶת הַצָּוֶת בְּמַהֵר לְהַצִּיל אֶת הַמַּצָּב. (He dispatched the team quickly to save the situation.)

hitshaleach.root_meaning: Related to sending, releasing, or extending

examples.hebrew: הִתְשַׁלַּחְתִּי לְעֶזְרָתוֹ בְּלִי לַחְשֹׁב מָתַי אֶחְזֹר.
examples.transliteration: Hitshaláchtí le-ezrató be-lí lachshóv matái echzór.
examples.translation: I extended myself to help him without thinking when I’d return.
The tendrils extend themselves far in nature.

examples.hebrew: נִתְשַׁלֵּחַ לְסַיֵּעַ אִם יִהְיֶה צֹרֶךְ בַּחֵרוּם.
examples.transliteration: Nitshaléach le-sayéa im yihyé tzórek ba-cherúm.
examples.translation: We will extend ourselves to assist if there’s an emergency need.

hitshaleach.notes: Hitpa'el indicates reflexive or intensive action. For שׁ.ל.ח, it means 'to extend oneself' (reflexively reaching out or stretching) or 'to be sent forth' (intensive passive). It’s less common in modern Hebrew, often used figuratively for effort or natural extension, contrasting with Pa'al’s direct 'to send'.

idioms.usage: הַצְּמָחִים הִתְשַׁלְּחוּ לְכָל הָרוּחוֹת בַּגִּנָּה. (The plants extended in all directions in the garden.)

hashliach.root_meaning: Related to sending, releasing, or extending

examples.hebrew: הִשְׁלַחְתִּי אֶת הַיּוֹנָה לִרְאוֹת אִם הַמַּיִם יָרְדוּ.
examples.transliteration: Hishláchtí et ha-yoná lir’ót im ha-máyim yardú.
examples.translation: I released the dove to see if the waters had receded.

examples.hebrew: הַמְּנַהֵל מַשְׁלִיחַ אֶת הַמִּכְתָּבִים לִשְׁלוֹחַ בַּדֹּאר.
examples.transliteration: Ha-menhél mashlíach et ha-michtavím lishlóach ba-dóar.
examples.translation: The manager causes the letters to be sent by mail.

examples.hebrew: אַשְׁלִיחַ אֶת הַחֲבֵרִים לְשַׁלֵּחַ אֶת הַצִּיּוּד מָחָר.
examples.transliteration: Ashlíach et ha-chaverím leshaléach et ha-tziyúd máchar.
examples.translation: I will cause the friends to send the equipment tomorrow.

hashliach.notes: Hif'il is the causative form of Pa'al, shifting 'to send' into 'to cause to send' or 'to release'. In modern Hebrew, 'to release' is more common (e.g., letting go of objects or animals), while 'to cause to send' is less frequent but used in contexts like directing others to dispatch. It’s moderately common, especially for physical release.

idioms.usage: הוּא הִשְׁלִיחַ אֶת הָרוּחַ וְהִתְחִיל לְרַקֵּד. (He let loose and started dancing.)

hushlach.root_meaning: Related to sending, releasing, or extending

examples.hebrew: הַצִּיּוּד הֻשְׁלַח לַמַּחְסָן עַל יְדֵי הַמַּנְהֵל.
examples.transliteration: Ha-tziyúd hushlách la-machsán al yedéi ha-manhél.
examples.translation: The equipment was sent to the warehouse by the manager.
The doves are sent to fly at the peace ceremony.

examples.hebrew: הַחֲיָלִים יֻשְׁלְחוּ לַקְּרָב אִם הַמַּצָּב יַחְמִיר.
examples.transliteration: Ha-chayalím yushlechú la-kráv im ha-matzáv yachmír.
examples.translation: The soldiers will be sent to battle if the situation worsens.

hushlach.notes: Huf'al is the passive form of Hif'il, turning 'to cause to send' or 'to release' into 'to be sent'. It’s rare in modern spoken Hebrew, appearing mostly in formal or written contexts, overlapping with Nif'al ('to be sent') but with a stronger causative nuance from Hif'il’s 'release'.

idioms.usage: הַצָּוֶת הֻשְׁלַח לְרַחוֹק לְבַדֹּק אֶת הַשֵּׁטַח. (The team was sent far away to inspect the area.)

naasah.root_meaning: Related to doing, making, or performing

examples.hebrew: הָעֲבוֹדָה נַעֲשְׂתָה בְּזֹאת עַל יְדֵי הַתַּלְמִידִים.
examples.transliteration: Ha’avodá na’astáh be-zót al yedéi ha-talmidím.
examples.translation: The work was done by the students.
The eggs are made in a pan every morning.

examples.hebrew: הַתּוֹכְנִית תֵּעָשֶׂה אִם נִמְצָא אֶת הַזְּמַן הַמַּתְאִים.
examples.transliteration: Ha-tochnít té’aséh im nimtzá et ha-zman ha-mat’ím.
examples.translation: The plan will be done if we find the right time.

naasah.notes: Nif'al is the passive form of Pa'al, turning 'to do' or 'to make' into 'to be done' or 'to be made'. It’s very common in modern Hebrew, used for both literal actions (e.g., cooking) and abstract completions (e.g., tasks), making it a versatile and frequent form.

idioms.usage: הַכֹּל נַעֲשָׂה בְּרֶגַע כְּשֶׁהִגִּיעַ הַזְּמַן. (Everything was done in a moment when the time came.)

meaning: to be caused to be done

iseh.root_meaning: Related to doing, making, or performing

examples.translation: I performed the commandment with great joy.
The student performs the task with precision.

examples.hebrew: אֲעַשֵּׂה אֶת הַתַּרְגִּיל לְפִי הַהוֹרָאוֹת מָחָר.
examples.transliteration: A’aséh et ha-targíl le-fí ha-horá’ót máchar.
examples.translation: I will execute the exercise according to the instructions tomorrow.

iseh.notes: Pi'el intensifies the Pa'al meaning ('to do' or 'to make') into 'to perform' or 'to execute', emphasizing a deliberate or skilled act. It’s moderately common in modern Hebrew, often used for specific tasks or duties, contrasting with Pa'al’s broader usage.

idioms.usage: הוּא עִשֵּׂה אֶת הַמְּלָאכָה בְּיָדַיִם בְּכָל הַלֵּב. (He performed the craft by hand with all his heart.)

meaning: to be caused to be done

useh.root_meaning: Related to doing, making, or performing

examples.hebrew: הַמִּצְוָה עֻשְּׂתָה בְּקֹדֶשׁ עַל יְדֵי הַכֹּהֵן.
examples.transliteration: Ha-mitzvá ushtáh be-kódesh al yedéi ha-kohén.
examples.translation: The commandment was performed in holiness by the priest.

examples.hebrew: הַמִּשְׂימוֹת מְעֻשּׂוֹת בְּדִיּוּק עַל יְדֵי הַצָּוֶת.
examples.transliteration: Ha-mismót me’ushót be-diyúk al yedéi ha-tzavet.
examples.translation: The tasks are executed precisely by the team.
The exercise will be performed during the next hour.

useh.notes: Pu'al is the passive form of Pi'el, turning 'to perform' or 'to execute' into 'to be performed' or 'to be executed'. It’s rare in modern spoken Hebrew, appearing mostly in formal or written contexts to emphasize an intensive or deliberate act being completed, overlapping with Nif'al ('to be done') but tied to Pi'el’s specificity.

idioms.usage: הַמְּלָאכָה מְעֻשָּׂה בְּדִיּוּק לְפִי הַתָּכְנִית. (The work is performed with precision according to the plan.)

meaning: to be caused to be done

hitaseh.root_meaning: Related to doing, making, or performing

examples.translation: I busied myself with fixing the house all day.

examples.hebrew: הִיא מִתְעַשָּׂה בְּעִנְיָנֵי הַבֵּית בְּכָל עֵת פְּנוּיָה.
examples.transliteration: Hi mit’asáh be-inyanéi ha-báyit be-chól et penuyá.
examples.translation: She engages herself in household matters whenever she’s free.

examples.hebrew: נִתְעַשֵּׂה בְּתַכְנּוּן הַמְּסִבָּה אִם תִּרְצוּ לָבוֹא.
examples.transliteration: Nit’aséh be-tachnún ha-mesibá im tirtzú lavó.
examples.translation: We will busy ourselves with planning the party if you want to come.

hitaseh.notes: Hitpa'el indicates reflexive or intensive action. For ע.ש.ה, it means 'to busy oneself' (reflexively engaging in activity) or 'to be engaged' (intensive involvement). It’s moderately common in modern Hebrew, often used for personal involvement in tasks or occupations, contrasting with Pa'al’s general 'to do'.

idioms.usage: הוּא הִתְעַשֵּׂה בְּכָל הַלֵּב בְּעֶזְרַת הַחֲבֵרִים. (He busied himself wholeheartedly helping his friends.)

meaning: to be caused to be done

haasot.root_meaning: Related to doing, making, or performing

examples.hebrew: הֶעֱשֵׂיתִי אֶת הַיֶּלֶד לְנַקּוֹת אֶת הַחֶדֶר.
examples.transliteration: He’eséiti et ha-yéled lenakót et ha-chéder.
examples.translation: I caused the child to clean the room.

examples.hebrew: הַמּוֹרֶה מַעֲשֶׂה אֶת הַתַּלְמִידִים לְעַשּׂוֹת שִׁעוּרִים.
examples.transliteration: Ha-moré ma’aséh et ha-talmidím le’asót shi’urím.
examples.translation: The teacher induces the students to do homework.

examples.hebrew: אַעֲשֶׂה אֶת הַצָּוֶת לְתַכְנֵן אֶת הַמְּסִבָּה מָחָר.
examples.transliteration: A’aséh et ha-tzavét letachnén et ha-mesibá máchar.
examples.translation: I will cause the team to plan the party tomorrow.

haasot.notes: Hif'il is the causative form of Pa'al, shifting 'to do' into 'to cause to do' or 'to induce'. In modern Hebrew, it’s moderately common, often used to describe prompting others to act or complete tasks, adding a layer of agency beyond Pa'al’s direct action.

idioms.translation: caused to do with a fresh mind
idioms.usage: הוּא הֶעֱשָׂה אֶת הַעֲבוֹדָה בְּרֹאשׁ חָדָשׁ לְאַחַר הַחֲגִים. (He caused the work to be done with a fresh mind after the holidays.)

meaning: to be caused to be done

huasot.root_meaning: Related to doing, making, or performing
meaning: to be caused to be done
