infinitive.translation: to be caused to be done

examples.hebrew: הַחֶדֶר הֻעֲשָׂה לְהִנָּקוֹת עַל יְדֵי הַיֶּלֶד.
examples.transliteration: Ha-chéder hu’asáh lehinakót al yedéi ha-yéled.
examples.translation: The room was caused to be cleaned by the child.

examples.hebrew: שִׁעוּרִים מֻעֲשִׂים לְהֵעָשׂוֹת עַל יְדֵי הַתַּלְמִידִים מדי יוֹם.
examples.transliteration: Shi’urím mu’asím lehé’asót al yedéi ha-talmidím mei yom.
examples.translation: Homework is induced to be done by the students every day.

examples.hebrew: הַמְּסִבָּה תֻּעֲשֶׂה לְהִתְכַּנֵּן אִם הַצָּוֶת יֵעָשֶׂה.
examples.transliteration: Ha-mesibá tu’aséh lehitkanén im ha-tzavét yé’aséh.
examples.translation: The party will be caused to be planned if the team is induced to do it.

huasot.notes: Huf'al is the passive form of Hif'il, turning 'to cause to do' or 'to induce' into 'to be caused to be done' or 'to be induced'. It’s rare in modern spoken Hebrew, appearing mostly in formal or written contexts, often overlapping with Nif'al ('to be done') but with a stronger causative nuance from Hif'il.

idioms.translation: caused to be done by force
idioms.usage: הָעֲבוֹדָה הֻעֲשְׂתָה בְּכֹחַ עַל יְדֵי הַמַּנְהִיגִים. (The work was caused to be done by force by the leaders.)

meaning: to be caused to be done

nodah.root_meaning: Related to knowing, understanding, or informing

examples.translation: The secret was known to everyone after the meeting.
The students are known for their wisdom in the school.

examples.hebrew: הַחֲדָשׁוֹת יִוָּדְעוּ לְכָל הָעָם בְּעוֹד שָׁעָה.
examples.transliteration: Ha-chadashót yivad’ú le-chól ha’am be-ód sha’á.
examples.translation: The news will be known to all the people in an hour.

nodah.notes: Nif'al is the passive form of Pa'al, turning 'to know' into 'to be known'. It’s widely used in modern Hebrew to indicate something becoming known or recognized, making it a frequent and versatile form.

idioms.usage: הַסִּפּוּר נוֹדַע לְרַבִּים בְּזֹאת הַשָּׁנָה. (The story became known to many this year.)

meaning: to be caused to be known

yidea.root_meaning: Related to knowing, understanding, or informing

examples.hebrew: יִדַּעְתִּי אֶת הַתַּלְמִידִים עַל הַשִּׁנוּי בַּתָּכְנִית.
examples.transliteration: Yida’tí et ha-talmidím al ha-shinúi ba-tachnít.
examples.translation: I informed the students about the change in the plan.

examples.hebrew: הַמּוֹרָה מְיַדַּעַת אֶת הַהוֹרִים בְּעִנְיְנֵי הַיְּלָדִים.
examples.transliteration: Ha-morá meyada’at et ha-horím be-inyenéi ha-yeladím.
examples.translation: The teacher informs the parents about the children’s matters.

examples.hebrew: אֲיַדֵּעַ אֶת כֻּלָּם עַל הַתַּאֲרִיךְ הַחָדָשׁ מָחָר.
examples.transliteration: Ayadéa et kulám al ha-ta’arích ha-chadásh máchar.
examples.translation: I will make known to everyone the new date tomorrow.

yidea.notes: Pi'el intensifies the Pa'al meaning ('to know') into 'to inform' or 'to make known', emphasizing an active dissemination of knowledge. While less common than Hif'il (הוֹדִיעַ) for 'to inform' in modern Hebrew, it’s still meaningful and used in specific contexts, often with a sense of deliberate notification.

idioms.usage: הוּא יִדֵּעַ אֶת הַצָּוֶת בְּרֹאשׁ לִפְנֵי הַפְּגִישָׁה. (He informed the team upfront before the meeting.)

meaning: to be caused to be known

yuda.root_meaning: Related to knowing, understanding, or informing

examples.hebrew: הַתַּלְמִידִים יֻדַּעְתֶּם עַל הַשִּׁנוּי עַל יְדֵי הַמּוֹרָה.
examples.transliteration: Ha-talmidím yuda’tem al ha-shinúi al yedéi ha-morá.
examples.translation: The students were informed about the change by the teacher.

examples.hebrew: הַהוֹרִים מְיֻדָּעִים בְּעִנְיְנֵי הַיְּלָדִים בְּכָל יוֹם.
examples.transliteration: Ha-horím meyuda’ím be-inyenéi ha-yeladím be-chól yom.
examples.translation: The parents are made known about the children’s matters every day.

examples.hebrew: כֻּלָּם יְיֻדְּעוּ עַל הַתַּאֲרִיךְ אִם אֲיַדֵּעַ אֶת הַמּוֹרָה.
examples.transliteration: Kulám yeyud’ú al ha-ta’arích im ayadéa et ha-morá.
examples.translation: Everyone will be informed about the date if I inform the teacher.

yuda.notes: Pu'al is the passive form of Pi'el, turning 'to inform' into 'to be informed' or 'to be made known'. It’s less common in modern Hebrew, often overshadowed by Huf'al (הוּדַע) or Nif'al (נוֹדַע), but appears in formal or written contexts to emphasize the intensive act of being notified.

idioms.usage: הַסּוֹד מְיֻדָּע בְּרַבִּים אַחֲרֵי הַשְּׁמוּעוֹת. (The secret was made known to many after the rumors.)

meaning: to be caused to be known

hityadea.root_meaning: Related to knowing, understanding, or informing

examples.translation: I made myself known to everyone during the meeting.

examples.hebrew: הַתַּלְמִיד מִתְיַדֵּעַ לְחֲבֵרָיו בְּכָל יוֹם חָדָשׁ.
examples.transliteration: Ha-talmíd mityadéa le-chaveráv be-chól yom chadásh.
examples.translation: The student becomes acquainted with his friends every new day.

examples.hebrew: נִתְיַדֵּעַ לָעָם אִם נְסַפֵּר אֶת הַסִּפּוּר שֶׁלָּנוּ.
examples.transliteration: Nityadéa la’ám im nesapér et ha-sipúr shelánu.
examples.translation: We will make ourselves known to the people if we tell our story.

hityadea.notes: Hitpa'el indicates reflexive or intensive action. For י.ד.ע, it means 'to make oneself known' (actively revealing oneself) or 'to become acquainted' (intensively engaging in knowing others). It’s less common in modern Hebrew, often appearing in formal or literary contexts, but remains meaningful compared to Pa'al’s direct 'to know' or Hif'il’s 'to inform'.

idioms.translation: made oneself known with a fresh start
idioms.usage: הוּא הִתְיַדֵּעַ בְּרֹאשׁ חָדָשׁ לְאַחַר הַמַּעֲבָר. (He made himself known with a fresh start after the move.)

meaning: to be caused to be known

huda.root_meaning: Related to knowing, understanding, or informing
meaning: to be caused to be known

examples.hebrew: הַתַּלְמִידִים הוּדְעוּ עַל הַשִּׁנוּי עַל יְדֵי הַמּוֹרָה.
examples.transliteration: Ha-talmidím hud’ú al ha-shinúi al yedéi ha-morá.
examples.translation: The students were informed about the change by the teacher.

examples.hebrew: הַהוֹרִים מֻדָּעִים לְעִנְיְנֵי הַיְּלָדִים בְּכָל עֵת.
examples.transliteration: Ha-horím muda’ím le-inyenéi ha-yeladím be-chól et.
examples.translation: The parents are caused to be known about the children’s matters at all times.

examples.hebrew: הַחֲדָשׁוֹת יּוּדְעוּ לְכֻלָּם אִם הַמּוֹרֶה יוֹדִיעַ.
examples.transliteration: Ha-chadashót yud’ú le-kulám im ha-moré yodía.
examples.translation: The news will be informed to everyone if the teacher informs.

huda.notes: Huf'al is the passive form of Hif'il, turning 'to cause to know' or 'to inform' into 'to be caused to be known' or 'to be informed'. It’s moderately used in modern Hebrew, often in formal or written contexts, overlapping with Nif'al ('to be known') and Pu'al ('to be informed') but tied to Hif'il’s causative action.
similar_verbs: הֻעֲשׂוֹת (to be caused to be done)

idioms.usage: הַסּוֹד הוּדַע בְּרַבִּים אַחֲרֵי הַדְּלִיפָה. (The secret was informed to many after the leak.)

meaning: to be caused to be known

nechayah.root_meaning: Related to living, sustaining, or reviving

examples.hebrew: הַתַּפְקִיד נֶחְיָה עַל יְדֵי הַשַּׂחְקָן בְּמִיּוּמָּנוּת.
examples.transliteration: Ha-tafkíd nechyáh al yedéi ha-sachkán be-miyumanút.
examples.translation: The role was lived skillfully by the actor.
The village life is lived in peace and tranquility.
The dream will be lived if we make an effort.

nechayah.notes: Nif'al is the passive form of Pa'al, turning 'to live' into 'to be lived' or 'to be sustained'. It’s moderately common in modern Hebrew, often used to describe how life or roles are experienced or maintained passively, complementing Pa'al’s active sense.

idioms.usage: הַתַּפְקִיד נֶחְיָה בְּשׁוֹטֵף עַל יְדֵי הַמְּנַהֵל הַחָדָשׁ. (The role was lived fluently by the new manager.)

chiyah.root_meaning: Related to living, sustaining, or reviving

examples.translation: I sustained the plants with water and sunlight.
The doctor revives the patients with skill.
I will revive the old memories with stories.

chiyah.notes: Pi'el intensifies Pa'al’s 'to live' into 'to sustain life' or 'to revive', implying an active effort to maintain or restore vitality. It’s moderately common in modern Hebrew, often used for sustaining life (plants, animals) or reviving (people, memories), contrasting with Pa'al’s simpler sense of living.

idioms.usage: הַמּוּזִיקָה חִיְּתָה אֶת הָרוּחַ בַּמְּסִבָּה. (The music revived the spirit at the party.)

chuyah.root_meaning: Related to living, sustaining, or reviving

examples.hebrew: הַצְּמָחִים חֻיּוּ בְּמַיִם עַל יְדֵי הַגַּנָּן.
examples.transliteration: Ha-tzmachím chuyú be-máyim al yedéi ha-ganán.
examples.translation: The plants were sustained with water by the gardener.

examples.hebrew: הַחוֹלִים מְחֻיִּים בְּטִפּוּל רְפוּאִי בַּבֵּית חוֹלִים.
examples.transliteration: Ha-cholím mechuyím be-tipúl refu’í ba-béit cholím.
examples.translation: The patients are revived with medical care in the hospital.

examples.hebrew: הַזִּכְרוֹנוֹת יְחֻיּוּ בְּסִפּוּרִים אִם נְסַפֵּר אוֹתָם.
examples.transliteration: Ha-zichronót yechuyú be-sipurím im nesapér otám.
examples.translation: The memories will be revived with stories if we tell them.

chuyah.notes: Pu'al is the passive form of Pi'el, turning 'to sustain life' or 'to revive' into 'to be sustained' or 'to be revived'. It’s less common in modern spoken Hebrew, appearing mostly in formal or written contexts, often overlapping with Nif'al ('to be lived') but emphasizing the intensive act of sustenance or revival from Pi'el.

idioms.usage: הַתַּרְבּוּת מְחֻיָּה בְּרֹוחַ עַל יְדֵי הַדּוֹרוֹת. (The culture is sustained with breadth by the generations.)

hitchayah.root_meaning: Related to living, sustaining, or reviving

examples.hebrew: הִתְחַיֵּיתִי עִם מַיִם קָרִים אַחֲרֵי הַטִּיּוּל.
examples.transliteration: Hitchayéiti im máyim karím acharéi ha-tiyúl.
examples.translation: I revived myself with cold water after the hike.
The city comes alive on summer nights.

examples.hebrew: נִתְחַיֶּה עִם מוּזִיקָה אִם תָּבוֹא לָרְקֹד.
examples.transliteration: Nitchayéh im múzika im tavó larkód.
examples.translation: We will revive ourselves with music if you come to dance.

hitchayah.notes: Hitpa'el indicates reflexive or intensive action. For ח.י.ה, it means 'to revive oneself' (reflexively restoring vitality) or 'to come alive' (intensively gaining energy). It’s moderately common in modern Hebrew, often used for personal renewal or lively states, complementing Pa'al’s basic 'to live'.

idioms.usage: הַיַּעַר הִתְחַיָּה מֵחָדָשׁ אַחֲרֵי הַגְּשָׁמִים. (The forest came alive anew after the rains.)

hachayah.root_meaning: Related to living, sustaining, or reviving

examples.translation: I revived the patient with artificial respiration.

examples.hebrew: הַמּוּזִיקָה מַחֲיָה אֶת הַקָּהָל בְּכָל הוֹפָעָה.
examples.transliteration: Ha-múzika machayáh et ha-kahál be-chól hofa’á.
examples.translation: The music revives the audience at every performance.

examples.hebrew: אַחֲיֶה אֶת הַצְּמָחִים הַיְּבֵשִׁים עִם מַיִם מָחָר.
examples.transliteration: Achayéh et ha-tzmachím ha-yeveshím im máyim máchar.
examples.translation: I will revive the dry plants with water tomorrow.

hachayah.notes: Hif'il is the causative form of Pa'al, shifting 'to live' into 'to cause to live' or 'to revive'. It’s highly common in modern Hebrew, used both literally (e.g., reviving a patient) and figuratively (e.g., reviving spirits or objects), making it more frequent than Pi'el or Hitpa'el forms of this root.

idioms.usage: הַחִיּוּךְ שֶׁלָּהּ הֶחֱיָה אֶת הַלֵּב שֶׁלִּי. (Her smile revived my heart.)

huchayah.root_meaning: Related to living, sustaining, or reviving

examples.hebrew: הַחוֹלֶה הֻחֲיָה עַל יְדֵי הָרוֹפֵא בְּבֵית הַחוֹלִים.
examples.transliteration: Ha-cholé huchayáh al yedéi ha-rofé be-véit ha-cholím.
examples.translation: The patient was revived by the doctor in the hospital.

examples.hebrew: הַצְּמָחִים מֻחֲיִים עַל יְדֵי הַגְּשָׁמִים בְּכָל עוֹנָה.
examples.transliteration: Ha-tzmachím muchayím al yedéi ha-geshamím be-chól oná.
examples.translation: The plants are revived by the rains every season.

examples.hebrew: הַזִּכְרוֹנוֹת יֻחֲיוּ עַל יְדֵי הַשִּׁירִים הַיְּשָׁנִים.
examples.transliteration: Ha-zichronót yuchayú al yedéi ha-shirím ha-yeshaním.
examples.translation: The memories will be revived by the old songs.

huchayah.notes: Huf'al is the passive form of Hif'il, turning 'to cause to live' or 'to revive' into 'to be caused to live' or 'to be revived'. It’s rare in modern spoken Hebrew, appearing mostly in formal or written contexts, overlapping with Nif'al ('to be lived') or Pu'al ('to be revived') but emphasizing the causative origin from Hif'il.
similar_verbs: לְהֻעֲשׂוֹת (to be caused to be done)

idioms.usage: הַקָּהָל הֻחֲיָה בְּרֶגַע עַל יְדֵי הַנְאוּם הַמַּרְגֵּשׁ. (The audience was revived in a moment by the stirring speech.)

nechshav.root_meaning: Related to thinking, calculating, or considering

examples.hebrew: הָרַעְיוֹן נֶחְשַׁב חָשׁוּב עַל יְדֵי כֻּלָּם.
examples.transliteration: Ha-ra’ayón nechsháv chashúv al yedéi kulám.
examples.translation: The idea was thought important by everyone.
The students are considered wise in the school.

examples.hebrew: הַפִּתְרוֹן יֵחָשֵׁב נָכוֹן אִם נִבְדֹּק אוֹתוֹ.
examples.transliteration: Ha-pit’rón yéchashev nachón im nivdók otó.
examples.translation: The solution will be thought correct if we check it.

nechshav.notes: Nif'al is the passive form of Pa'al, turning 'to think' into 'to be thought' or 'to be considered'. It’s widely used in modern Hebrew to express being regarded or evaluated, making it a common and versatile form.

idioms.usage: הַפְּרוֹיֶקְט נֶחְשַׁב בְּרֹאשׁ בְּתוֹכְנִית הַשָּׁנָה. (The project was thought at the forefront of the year’s plan.)

chishev.root_meaning: Related to thinking, calculating, or considering

examples.hebrew: חִשַּׁבְתִּי אֶת הַסְּכוּם שֶׁל הַחֶשְׁבּוֹן בְּדִיּוּק.
examples.transliteration: Chishávti et ha-skum shel ha-cheshbón be-diyúk.
examples.translation: I calculated the sum of the bill precisely.
The student calculates the answer quickly.

examples.hebrew: אֲחַשֵּׁב אֶת הַזְּמַן שֶׁנִּדְרָשׁ לָנוּ מָחָר.
examples.transliteration: Achashév et ha-zman shenidrásh lánu máchar.
examples.translation: I will compute the time we need tomorrow.

chishev.notes: Pi'el intensifies the Pa'al meaning ('to think') into 'to calculate' or 'to compute', emphasizing a deliberate or precise act of reckoning. It’s moderately common in modern Hebrew, often used for mathematical or logistical computations, contrasting with Pa'al’s broader sense of thinking.

idioms.usage: הוּא חִשֵּׁב בְּדִיּוּק אֶת הַמִּסְפָּרִים לִפְנֵי הַפְּגִישָׁה. (He calculated the numbers precisely before the meeting.)

chushav.root_meaning: Related to thinking, calculating, or considering

examples.hebrew: הַסְּכוּם הכולל חֻשַּׁב על ידי המחשב במהירות.
examples.transliteration: Ha-skúm ha-kolél chusháv al yedéi ha-machshév be-mehirút.
examples.translation: The total sum was calculated by the computer quickly.

examples.hebrew: הַתְּשׁוּבוֹת מְחֻשָּׁבוֹת בְּדִיּוּק עַל יְדֵי הַתַּלְמִידִים.
examples.transliteration: Ha-tshuvót mechushavót be-diyúk al yedéi ha-talmidím.
examples.translation: The answers are computed precisely by the students.
The time will be calculated after we finish the test.

chushav.notes: Pu'al is the passive form of Pi'el, turning 'to calculate' into 'to be calculated' or 'to be computed'. It’s moderately common in modern Hebrew, especially in technical or formal contexts like mathematics or logistics, aligning with Pi'el’s intensive focus and contrasting with Nif'al’s broader 'to be thought'.

idioms.usage: הַתַּקְצִיב מְחֻשָּׁב לְמִנְיָן הַשָּׁנִים הַבָּאוֹת. (The budget is calculated for the coming years.)

hitchashev.root_meaning: Related to thinking, calculating, or considering

examples.hebrew: הִתְחַשַּׁבְתִּי לְחָכָם אַחֲרֵי שֶׁפָּתַרְתִּי אֶת הַחִידָה.
examples.transliteration: Hitchashávti le-chachám acharei she-patárti et ha-chidá.
examples.translation: I considered myself wise after solving the riddle.

examples.hebrew: הִיא מִתְחַשֶּׁבֶת בְּרֹאשׁ כְּשֶׁהִיא מְתַכְנֶנֶת אֶת הַיּוֹם.
examples.transliteration: Hi mitchashevet be-rósh kshe-hi metaknénet et ha-yóm.
examples.translation: She takes her mind into account when planning the day.

examples.hebrew: נִתְחַשֵּׁב עִם הַזְּמַן שֶׁיֵּשׁ לָנוּ לִפְנֵי הַפְּגִישָׁה.
examples.transliteration: Nitcashév im ha-zmán she-yésh lánu lifnéi ha-pegishá.
examples.translation: We will take into account the time we have before the meeting.

hitchashev.notes: Hitpa'el indicates reflexive or intensive action. For ח.ש.ב, it means 'to consider oneself' (reflexively evaluating one’s own status) or 'to take into account' (intensively reckoning with something). It’s moderately common in modern Hebrew, often used for self-assessment or careful consideration, contrasting with Pa'al’s general 'to think'.

idioms.usage: הוּא הִתְחַשֵּׁב לְמַעְלָה אַחֲרֵי שֶׁזָּכָה בַּפְּרָס. (He considered himself above after winning the prize.)

hechshiv.root_meaning: Related to thinking, calculating, or considering

examples.hebrew: הֶחְשַׁבְתִּי אֶת הָרַעְיוֹן לְחָשׁוּב לִפְנֵי שֶׁדִּבַּרְתִּי.
examples.transliteration: Hechshávti et ha-ra’ayón le-chashúv lifnéi she-dibárti.
examples.translation: I considered the idea important before I spoke.

examples.hebrew: הַמּוֹרֶה מַחְשִׁיב אֶת הַמִּשְׂימָה לְקָשָׁה מְאֹד.
examples.transliteration: Ha-moré machshív et ha-mismá le-kashá me’ód.
examples.translation: The teacher deems the task very difficult.

examples.hebrew: אַחְשִׁיב אֶת דַּעְתְּךָ כְּשֶׁאֶחְלִיט עַל הַתָּכְנִית.
examples.transliteration: Achshív et da’atchá kshe-echlít al ha-tochnít.
examples.translation: I will consider your opinion when I decide on the plan.

hechshiv.notes: Hif'il is the causative form of Pa'al, shifting 'to think' into 'to consider' or 'to deem', implying causing something to be regarded in a certain way. It’s moderately common in modern Hebrew, often used to express valuing or assessing, complementing Pa'al’s general thinking and Pi’el’s specific calculation.

idioms.usage: הוּא הֶחְשִׁיב לְלֵב אֶת הָעֵצָה שֶׁנָּתַן לוֹ חָבֵר. (He took to heart the advice his friend gave him.)

huchshav.root_meaning: Related to thinking, calculating, or considering

examples.hebrew: הָרַעְיוֹן הֻחְשַׁב חָשׁוּב עַל יְדֵי הַצָּוֶת.
examples.transliteration: Ha-ra’ayón huchsháv chashúv al yedéi ha-tzavét.
examples.translation: The idea was deemed important by the team.

examples.hebrew: הַמִּשְׂימוֹת מֻחְשָׁבוֹת קָשׁוֹת בְּבֵית הַסֵּפֶר הַזֶּה.
examples.transliteration: Ha-mismót muchshavót kashót be-véit ha-séfer ha-zé.
examples.translation: The tasks are considered difficult in this school.

examples.hebrew: הַתָּכְנִית תֻּחְשַׁב מֻצְלַחַת אִם נַשְׁלִים אוֹתָהּ בַּזְּמַן.
examples.transliteration: Ha-tochnít tuchsháv mutzlächat im nashlím otáh ba-zmán.
examples.translation: The plan will be deemed successful if we complete it on time.

huchshav.notes: Huf'al is the passive form of Hif'il, turning 'to consider' or 'to deem' into 'to be deemed' or 'to be considered'. It’s less common in modern spoken Hebrew, appearing mostly in formal or written contexts, overlapping with Nif'al ('to be thought') but tied to Hif'il’s causative nuance of valuing or assessing.
similar_verbs: לְהֻעֲשׂוֹת (to be caused to be done)

idioms.usage: הַמַּעֲשֶׂה הֻחְשַׁב לְטוֹבָה עַל יְדֵי הַקָּהָל. (The deed was deemed for the good by the community.)

examples.hebrew: הַשִּׁיר נִשְׁרָה בְּפִי הַזֹּמֵר עַל יְדֵי הַקָּהָל.
examples.transliteration: Ha-shir nishráh be-fí ha-zomér al yedéi ha-kahál.
examples.translation: The song was sung by the singer for the audience.

examples.hebrew: שִׁירֵי הַחֲגִים נָשָׁרִים בְּבֵית הַסֵּפֶר בְּכָל שָׁנָה.
examples.transliteration: Shiréi ha-chagím nasharím be-véit ha-séfer be-chól shaná.
examples.translation: Holiday songs are sung at school every year.

examples.hebrew: הַמָּנוֹת יִשְּׁרוּ בְּטֶקֶס אִם הַזֹּמְרִים יָבוֹאוּ.
examples.transliteration: Ha-mánot yishrú be-tékes im ha-zomrím yavó’u.
examples.translation: The hymns will be sung at the ceremony if the singers come.

nishar.notes: Nif'al is the passive form of Pa'al, turning 'to sing' (שר) into 'to be sung'. It’s moderately common in modern Hebrew, used for songs or melodies being performed passively, often in formal or communal contexts like ceremonies or celebrations.

idioms.usage: הַשִּׁיר הַזֶּה נָשָׁר בְּפִי כֻּלָּם בַּחֲגִיגוֹת. (This song was sung by everyone at the celebrations.)

meaning: to be caused to be sung

examples.hebrew: שִׁירֵי הַתְּהִלָּה שֻׁרְּרוּ בְּטֶקֶס עַל יְדֵי הַמַּקְהֵלָה.
examples.transliteration: Shiréi ha-tehilá shurrú be-tékes al yedéi ha-makhelá.
examples.translation: The hymns of praise were sung repeatedly at the ceremony by the choir.

examples.hebrew: הַשִּׁירִים הַאֵלֶּה מְשֻׁרָּרִים בְּמִסִּבּוֹת בְּכָל שָׁנָה.
examples.transliteration: Ha-shirím ha-éle meshurarím be-misibót be-chól shaná.
examples.translation: These songs are sung repeatedly at parties every year.

examples.hebrew: הַמָּנוֹת יְשֻׁרְּרוּ בְּיוֹם הַחֲגִיגָה אִם נַזְמִין זֹמְרִים.
examples.transliteration: Ha-mánot yeshurrú be-yóm ha-chagigá im nazmín zomrím.
examples.translation: The hymns will be sung repeatedly on the celebration day if we invite singers.

shurar.notes: Pu'al is the passive form of Pi'el, turning 'to sing praises' or 'to sing repeatedly' into 'to be sung repeatedly'. It’s less common in modern spoken Hebrew, appearing mostly in formal or literary contexts to emphasize repeated singing, overlapping with Nif'al ('to be sung') but with Pi'el’s intensive nuance.

idioms.usage: הַשִּׁירִים מְשֻׁרָּרִים בְּשִׂמְחָה בְּיוֹם הַחֲגִיגָה. (The songs are sung repeatedly with joy on the celebration day.)

meaning: to be caused to be sung

examples.hebrew: הִתְשַׁרַּרְתִּי בְּשִׁיר קָטָן בְּעֵת הַלִּכְתִּי לְבֵיתִי.
examples.transliteration: Hitsharárti be-shir katán be’ét hilchtí le-véiti.
examples.translation: I sang a little song to myself while walking home.

examples.hebrew: הִיא מִתְשַׁרֶּרֶת בְּשִׁירֵי עַם כְּשֶׁהִיא לְבַדָּהּ.
examples.transliteration: Hi mitsharéret be-shiréi am kshe-hí levadáh.
examples.translation: She sings folk songs to herself when she’s alone.

examples.hebrew: נִתְשַׁרֵּר בְּשִׁירֵי הַחֲגִים אִם נִהְיֶה בְּבֵית הַסֵּפֶר.
examples.transliteration: Nitsharér be-shiréi ha-chagím im nihyé be-véit ha-séfer.
examples.translation: We will sing holiday songs to ourselves if we’re at school.

hitsharer.notes: Hitpa'el indicates reflexive action. For שר, it means 'to sing to oneself', reflecting a personal or introspective act of singing. It’s less common in modern Hebrew, often used for private or casual singing, contrasting with Pa'al’s general 'to sing' (שר).
related_words: מִתְשַׁרֵּר (singing to oneself, rare as adjective)

idioms.translation: sang to oneself with a peaceful heart
idioms.usage: הִתְשַׁרַּרְתִּי בְּלֵב שָׁלוֹם בְּעֵת הַשְּׁלוֹם הַזֹּאת. (I sang to myself with a peaceful heart during this calm time.)

meaning: to be caused to be sung

examples.hebrew: הִשַּׁרְתִּי אֶת הַיְלָדִים לָשִׁיר שִׁירֵי חֲגִים.
examples.transliteration: Hishárti et ha-yeladím lashír shiréi chagím.
examples.translation: I caused the children to sing holiday songs.

examples.hebrew: הַמּוֹרָה מַשִּׁירָה אֶת הַתַּלְמִידִים בְּכָל שִׁעוּר.
examples.transliteration: Ha-morá mashíra et ha-talmidím be-chól shi’úr.
examples.translation: The teacher causes the students to sing in every class.

examples.hebrew: אַשִּׁיר אֶת הַקָּהָל לָשִׁיר בְּטֶקֶס הַחֲגִיגָה מָחָר.
examples.transliteration: Ashír et ha-kahál lashír be-tékes ha-chagigá máchar.
examples.translation: I will cause the audience to sing at the celebration ceremony tomorrow.

hashir.notes: Hif'il is the causative form of Pa'al, shifting 'to sing' (שר) into 'to cause to sing'. It’s moderately common in modern Hebrew, often used in educational or performative contexts where someone prompts others to sing.
related_words: מַשִּׁיר (causing to sing, rare as adjective)

idioms.usage: הוּא הִשִּׁיר אֶת הַקָּהָל בְּקוֹל רָם בַּחֲגִיגוֹת. (He caused the audience to sing loudly at the celebrations.)

meaning: to be caused to be sung
to be caused to be sung

examples.hebrew: שִׁירֵי הַחֲגִים הֻשְּׁרוּ עַל יְדֵי הַיְלָדִים בְּהַדְרָכַת הַמּוֹרָה.
examples.transliteration: Shiréi ha-chagím hushrú al yedéi ha-yeladím be-hadrachát ha-morá.
examples.translation: The holiday songs were caused to be sung by the children under the teacher’s guidance.

examples.hebrew: הַשִּׁירִים הָאֵלֶּה מֻשָּׁרִים בְּטֶקֶסִים עַל יְדֵי הַמַּקְהֵלָה.
examples.transliteration: Ha-shirím ha-éle musharím be-tekasím al yedéi ha-makhelá.
examples.translation: These songs are caused to be sung at ceremonies by the choir.

examples.hebrew: הַמָּנוֹת יֻשְּׁרוּ בְּיוֹם הַחֲגִיגָה אִם הַזֹּמְרִים יִהְיוּ מוּכָנִים.
examples.transliteration: Ha-mánot yushrú be-yóm ha-chagigá im ha-zomrím yihyú muchaním.
examples.translation: The hymns will be caused to be sung on the celebration day if the singers are ready.

hushar.notes: Huf'al is the passive form of Hif'il, turning 'to cause to sing' into 'to be caused to be sung'. It’s rare in modern spoken Hebrew, appearing mostly in formal or written contexts, often overlapping with Nif'al ('to be sung') but with a stronger causative nuance from Hif'il.
related_words: מֻשָּׁר (caused to be sung, rare as adjective)
similar_verbs: לְהֻעֲשׂוֹת (to be caused to be done)

idioms.translation: caused to be sung with joy
idioms.usage: הַשִּׁירִים הֻשְּׁרוּ בְּשִׂמְחָה בְּיוֹם הַחֲגִיגָה. (The songs were caused to be sung with joy on the celebration day.)

meaning: to be caused to be sung

naratz.root_meaning: Related to running, hastening, or racing

examples.translation: The race was run quickly on the downhill course.

examples.hebrew: הַמִּסְלוּלִים נְרָצִים מדי יוֹם עַל יְדֵי הַתַּלְמִידִים.
examples.transliteration: Ha-mislulím nratzím mei yom al yedéi ha-talmidím.
examples.translation: The tracks are run every day by the students.

examples.hebrew: הַמֵּרוֹץ יֵרָץ בְּיֶתֶר מָהִירוּת אִם הַמַּזְגָן יִשָּׁאֵר פָּתוּחַ.
examples.transliteration: Ha-merótz yerátz be-yéter mahirút im ha-mazgán yishá’er patúach.
examples.translation: The race will be run faster if the air conditioning stays on.

naratz.notes: Nif'al is the passive form of Pa'al, turning 'to run' into 'to be run' or 'to be raced'. It’s moderately common in modern Hebrew, often used for races or courses being completed, contrasting with Pa'al’s active sense of running.

idioms.usage: הַמֵּרוֹץ נָרַץ בְּרֹאשׁ עַל יְדֵי הַתַּלְמִידִים הַמְּהִירִים. (The race was run at the head by the fastest students.)

meaning: to be caused to be run

ritzot.root_meaning: Related to running, hastening, or racing

examples.hebrew: רִצֵּיתִי אֶת הַמֵּרוֹץ כְּשֶׁרָאִיתִי אֶת הַגֶּשֶׁם מַתְקָרֵב.
examples.transliteration: Ritzéiti et ha-merótz kshe-ra’íti et ha-géshem matkarev.
examples.translation: I hastened the race when I saw the rain approaching.

examples.hebrew: הַמּוֹרֶה מְרַצֶּה אֶת הַתַּלְמִידִים לְהַגִּיעַ לְשִׁעוּרִים.
examples.transliteration: Ha-moré meratzéh et ha-talmidím lehagía le-shi’urím.
examples.translation: The teacher hastens the students to get to class.

examples.hebrew: אֲרַצֶּה אֶת הַתַּרְגִּילִים כְּדֵי לִפְנוֹת זֹאת עַד הָעֶרֶב.
examples.transliteration: Aratzéh et ha-targilím kedéi lifnót zot ad ha-érev.
examples.translation: I will accelerate the exercises to free up time by evening.

ritzot.notes: Pi'el intensifies the Pa'al meaning ('to run') into 'to hasten' or 'to accelerate', implying a deliberate or intensified act of speeding up. It’s less common in modern spoken Hebrew than Pa'al or Hif'il forms of 'rutz,' appearing more in formal or literary contexts.

idioms.usage: הוּא רִצֵּה אֶת הַדְּבָרִים כְּשֶׁהַזְּמַן הָיָה קָצָר. (He hastened the matters when time was short.)

meaning: to be caused to be run

rutzot.root_meaning: Related to running, hastening, or racing

examples.hebrew: הַמֵּרוֹץ רֻצֵּיתִי עַל יְדֵי הַמּוֹרֶה כְּשֶׁרָאִיתִי אֶת הַגֶּשֶׁם.
examples.transliteration: Ha-merótz rutzéiti al yedéi ha-moré kshe-ra’íti et ha-géshem.
examples.translation: The race was hastened by the teacher when I saw the rain.

examples.hebrew: הַתַּרְגִּילִים מְרֻצִּים עַל יְדֵי הַמַּנְהֵל לֵסִיּוּם מָהִיר.
examples.transliteration: Ha-targilím merutzím al yedéi ha-manhél lesiyúm mahír.
examples.translation: The exercises are hastened by the manager for a quick finish.

examples.hebrew: הַמִּסְלוּל יְרֻצֶּה אִם נִרְצֶה לְסַיֵּם לִפְנֵי הַחֹשֶׁךְ.
examples.transliteration: Ha-mislúl yerutzéh im nirtzéh lesayém lifnéi ha-chóshech.
examples.translation: The track will be hastened if we want to finish before dark.

rutzot.notes: Pu'al is the passive form of Pi'el, turning 'to hasten' into 'to be hastened'. It’s rare in modern spoken Hebrew, appearing mostly in formal or literary contexts to emphasize an intensified act of being sped up, overlapping slightly with Nif'al ('to be run') but tied to Pi'el’s deliberate hastening.

idioms.usage: הַמֵּרוֹץ מְרֻצֶּה בְּעֵת צֹרֶךְ לְהַצִּיל אֶת הַזְּמַן. (The race was hastened in time of need to save time.)

meaning: to be caused to be run

hitratzot.root_meaning: Related to running, hastening, or racing

translations.es: correr de un lado a otro

examples.hebrew: הִתְרַצֵּיתִי בֵּין הַחֲדָרִים לְחַפֵּשׂ אֶת הַמַּפְתֵּחַ.
examples.transliteration: Hitratzéiti béin ha-chadarím lechapés et ha-maftéach.
examples.translation: I ran about between the rooms to look for the key.

examples.hebrew: הַיְלָדִים מִתְרַצִּים בַּחֲצַר בְּכָל יוֹם אַחֲרֵי הַלִּמּוּדִים.
examples.transliteration: Ha-yeladím mitratzím ba-chatzár be-chól yom acharéi ha-limudím.
examples.translation: The children run about in the yard every day after school.

examples.hebrew: נִתְרַצֶּה בַּבַּיִת אִם תִּרְצוּ לְעַזֹּר לִי לְנַקּוֹת.
examples.transliteration: Nitratzéh ba-báyit im tirtzú la’azór li lenakót.
examples.translation: We will hurry ourselves around the house if you want to help me clean.

hitratzot.notes: Hitpa'el indicates reflexive or intensive action. For ר.ו.ץ, it means 'to run about' (reflexively moving in various directions) or 'to hurry oneself' (intensive self-directed haste). It’s moderately common in modern Hebrew, often used for energetic or scattered movement, contrasting with Pa'al’s straightforward 'to run'.

idioms.usage: הַיֶּלֶד הִתְרַצֵּה כְּמוֹ עֵגֶל בַּגִּנָּה הַחֲדָשָׁה. (The child ran about like a calf in the new garden.)

meaning: to be caused to be run

haritz.root_meaning: Related to running, hastening, or racing

examples.hebrew: הֲרַצְתִּי אֶת הַיְלָדִים לְרוץ לְפָנַי בַּמֵּרוֹץ.
examples.transliteration: Harátzti et ha-yeladím larútz lefanái ba-merótz.
examples.translation: I caused the children to run ahead of me in the race.

examples.hebrew: הַמּוֹרֶה מֵרִיץ אֶת הַתַּרְגִּילִים לְהִסָּיֵם בְּמָהִירוּת.
examples.transliteration: Ha-moré merítz et ha-targilím lehisayém be-mahirút.
examples.translation: The teacher accelerates the exercises to finish quickly.

examples.hebrew: אָרִיץ אֶת הַמִּסְלוּל לְהֵרָצוֹת אִם נִרְצֶה לְנַצֵּחַ.
examples.transliteration: Arítz et ha-mislúl leheratzót im nirtzéh lenatzéach.
examples.translation: I will cause the track to be run if we want to win.

haritz.notes: Hif'il is the causative form of Pa'al, shifting 'to run' into 'to cause to run' or 'to accelerate'. It’s moderately common in modern Hebrew, used both literally (e.g., making someone run) and figuratively (e.g., speeding up processes), contrasting with Pa'al’s direct action.

idioms.translation: caused the winds to run (stirred things up)
idioms.usage: הוּא הֵרִיץ אֶת הָרוּחוֹת בְּקֶרֶב הַצָּוֶת לְהַתְחִיל אֶת הַמֵּרוֹץ. (He stirred things up among the team to start the race.)

meaning: to be caused to be run

examples.transliteration: Ha-merótz hurátz al yedéi ha-moré lefanái ha-géshem.
examples.translation: The race was caused to be run by the teacher before the rain.

examples.hebrew: הַתַּרְגִּילִים מוּרָצִים עַל יְדֵי הַמַּנְהֵל לְסִיּוּם מָהִיר.

examples.transliteration: Ha-mislúl yurátz im nirtzéh lenatzéach ba-tacharút.

huratzot.notes: Huf'al is the passive form of Hif'il, turning 'to cause to run' or 'to accelerate' into 'to be caused to be run'. idioms.translation: caused to be run in time of need
idioms.usage: הַמֵּרוֹץ מוּרָץ בְּעֵת צֹרֶךְ לְהַגִּיעַ לַמַּטָּרָה. (The race was caused to be run in time of need to reach the goal.)

meaning: to be caused to be run

examples.hebrew: הַיֶּלֶד נֶאֱהַב עַל יְדֵי כֻּלָּם בַּגַּן.
examples.transliteration: Ha-yéled ne’eháv al yedéi kulám ba-gan.
examples.translation: The child was loved by everyone in the kindergarten.
This song is loved among the audience.

examples.hebrew: הַסֵּפֶר הַזֶּה יֵאָהֵב אִם יִתֻּרְגַּם לְעִבְרִית.
examples.transliteration: Ha-séfer ha-zé yé’ahév im yiturgám le-ivrít.
examples.translation: This book will be loved if it is translated into Hebrew.

neehav.notes: Nif'al is the passive form of Pa'al, turning 'to love' into 'to be loved'. It’s frequently used in modern Hebrew to express being the recipient of love or affection, making it a common and natural form for this root.

idioms.usage: הוּא נֶאֱהַב בְּכָל לֵב עַל יְדֵי מִשְׁפַּחְתּוֹ. (He was loved with all heart by his family.)

meaning: to be caused to be loved

examples.hebrew: אִהַּבְתִּי אֶת הַשִּׁיר לְחַבְרַי בְּקוֹל רָם.
examples.transliteration: Ihavtí et ha-shir le-chavrái be-kól ram.
examples.translation: I endeared the song to my friends with a loud voice.

examples.hebrew: הַיֶּלֶד מְאַהֵב אֶת עַצְמוֹ לְכֻלָּם בַּגַּן.
examples.transliteration: Ha-yéled me’ahév et atzmó le-kulám ba-gan.
examples.translation: The child endears himself to everyone in the kindergarten.

examples.hebrew: אֲאַהֵב אֶת הַסֵּפֶר לְךָ בְּעֶזְרַת הַתַּרְגּוּם.
examples.transliteration: A’ahév et ha-séfer lechá be-ezrat ha-targúm.
examples.translation: I will endear the book to you with the help of the translation.

ihev.notes: Pi'el intensifies the Pa'al meaning ('to love') into 'to endear' or 'to express love', emphasizing a deliberate or active expression of affection. It’s less common in modern Hebrew than Pa'al or Hitpa'el ('to fall in love'), appearing mostly in literary or formal contexts.

idioms.usage: הִיא מְאַהֶבֶת אֶת כֻּלָּם בְּלֵב פָּתוּחַ. (She endears everyone with an open heart.)

meaning: to be caused to be loved

examples.hebrew: הַשִּׁיר אֻהֲּבָה עַל יְדֵי הַמּוֹרָה בְּשִׁעוּר הַזֹּאת.
examples.transliteration: Ha-shir uhaváh al yedéi ha-morá be-shi’úr ha-zót.
examples.translation: The song was endeared by the teacher in this lesson.

examples.hebrew: הַיְלָדִים מְאֻהָּבִים עַל יְדֵי הַהוֹרִים בְּכָל יוֹם.
examples.transliteration: Ha-yeladím me’uhavím al yedéi ha-horím be-chól yom.
examples.translation: The children are endeared by the parents every day.

examples.hebrew: הַסֵּפֶר יְאֻהַּב אִם נְתַרְגֵּם אוֹתוֹ לְשָׂפוֹת נוֹסָפוֹת.
examples.transliteration: Ha-séfer ye’uháv im netargém otó le-safót nosafót.
examples.translation: The book will be endeared if we translate it into additional languages.

uhav.notes: Pu'al is the passive form of Pi'el, turning 'to endear' into 'to be endeared'. It’s rare in modern spoken Hebrew, appearing mostly in formal or literary contexts to describe being made lovable or cherished, contrasting with the more common Nif'al ('to be loved').

idioms.usage: הַיֶּלֶד מְאֻהָּב בְּלֵב כֻּלָּם בַּמִּשְׁפָּחָה. (The child is endeared in everyone’s heart in the family.)

meaning: to be caused to be loved

examples.translation: I fell in love with her the moment I met her.

examples.hebrew: הוּא מִתְאַהֵב בְּכָל סֵפֶר חָדָשׁ שֶׁיּוֹצֵא.
examples.transliteration: Hu mit’ahév be-chól séfer chadásh she-yotzé.
examples.translation: He falls in love with every new book that comes out.

examples.hebrew: אֶתְאַהֵב בַּמּוּסִיקָה אִם אֶשְׁמַע אוֹתָהּ שׁוּב.
examples.transliteration: Et’ahév ba-musíka im eshmá otáh shuv.
examples.translation: I will fall in love with the music if I hear it again.

hitahev.notes: Hitpa'el indicates reflexive or intensive action. For א.ה.ב, it primarily means 'to fall in love' (reflexive affection toward someone or something) and less commonly 'to make oneself loved'. It’s very common in modern Hebrew, especially in romantic contexts, contrasting with Pa'al’s general 'to love'.

idioms.translation: fell in love head and heart
idioms.usage: הִתְאַהֲבָה בּוֹ מֵרֹאשׁ וּמֵלֵב בַּפְּגִישָׁה הָרִאשׁוֹנָה. (She fell in love with him head and heart at the first meeting.)

meaning: to be caused to be loved

examples.hebrew: הֶאֱהַבְתִּי אֶת הַשִּׁיר לְחַבְרַי בְּשִׁירָה רַמָּה.
examples.transliteration: He’ahavtí et ha-shir le-chavrái be-shirá ramáh.
examples.translation: I caused my friends to love the song with loud singing.
The teacher causes the students to love the stories.

examples.hebrew: אַאֲהִיב אֶת הַסֵּפֶר לְךָ עִם תַּרְגּוּם קַל.
examples.transliteration: A’ahív et ha-séfer lechá im targúm kal.
examples.translation: I will cause you to love the book with an easy translation.

heehiv.notes: Hif'il is the causative form of Pa'al, shifting 'to love' into 'to cause to love'. In modern Hebrew, it’s moderately common, used to describe prompting others to develop affection or appreciation, contrasting with Pa'al’s direct 'to love' and Hitpa’el’s reflexive 'to fall in love'.

idioms.translation: causing to love with an open heart
idioms.usage: הוּא מַאֲהִיב אֶת הַמּוּסִיקָה בְּלֵב פָּתוּחַ לְכֻלָּם. (He causes everyone to love the music with an open heart.)

meaning: to be caused to be loved
to be caused to be loved

examples.hebrew: הַשִּׁיר הוּאֲהֲבָה עַל יְדֵי הַמּוֹרָה לַתַּלְמִידִים.
examples.transliteration: Ha-shir hu’ahaváh al yedéi ha-moráh la-talmidím.
examples.translation: The song was caused to be loved by the teacher for the students.

examples.hebrew: הַסֵּפֶר מוּאֲהָב עַל יְדֵי הַמְּתַרְגֵּם לְקוֹרְאֵי עִבְרִית.
examples.transliteration: Ha-séfer mu’aháv al yedéi ha-metargém le-kor’éi ivrít.
examples.translation: The book is caused to be loved by the translator for Hebrew readers.

examples.hebrew: הַמּוּסִיקָה תּוּאֲהַב אִם תּוּשְׁמַע בְּרַדְיוֹ הָרָשׁוּם.
examples.transliteration: Ha-musíka tu’aháv im tushmá be-radyó ha-rashúm.
examples.translation: The music will be caused to be loved if it is played on the official radio.

huahav.notes: Huf'al is the passive form of Hif'il, turning 'to cause to love' into 'to be caused to be loved'. It’s rare in modern spoken Hebrew, appearing mostly in formal or literary contexts, often overlapping with Nif'al ('to be loved') or Pu'al ('to be endeared') but with a stronger causative nuance tied to Hif'il.
similar_verbs: לְהוּאֲשׂוֹת (to be caused to be done)
לְהוּשְׁלַח (to be caused to be sent)

idioms.translation: caused to be loved in the audience’s heart
idioms.usage: הַשִּׁיר מוּאֲהָב בְּלֵב הַקָּהָל בִּזְכוּת הַמּוֹרָה. (The song was caused to be loved in the audience’s heart thanks to the teacher.)

meaning: to be caused to be loved

examples.hebrew: הָאִישׁ נִשְׂנָא עַל יְדֵי כֻּלָּם בַּכְּפָר.
examples.transliteration: Ha’ísh nisná al yedéi kulám ba-kfár.
examples.translation: The man was hated by everyone in the village.

examples.hebrew: הַסֵּפֶר הַזֶּה נִשְׂנָא בְּיָמֵינוּ עַל יְדֵי הַרְבֵּה אֲנָשִׁים.
examples.transliteration: Ha-séfer hazé nisná be-yaméinu al yedéi harbéh anashím.
examples.translation: This book is hated nowadays by many people.

examples.hebrew: הַמִּשְׂחָק יִשָּׂנֵא אִם לֹא יִשְׁתַּפֵּר בְּעוֹד זְמַן.
examples.transliteration: Ha-mischák yisané im lo yishtapér be’ód zmán.
examples.translation: The game will be hated if it doesn’t improve soon.

nisna.notes: Nif'al is the passive form of Pa'al, turning 'to hate' into 'to be hated'. It’s moderately common in modern Hebrew, often used to describe objects, people, or actions that are the recipients of hatred. Other binyanim like Pi'el ('to treat with hatred'), Pu'al ('to be treated with hatred'), and Hitpa'el ('to hate oneself') are rare in contemporary usage and mostly appear in literary or biblical contexts.

idioms.translation: hated in the eyes of the people
idioms.usage: הַמֶּלֶךְ נִשְׂנָא בְּעֵינֵי הָעָם בִּגְלַל הַמִּסִּים. (The king was hated in the eyes of the people because of the taxes.)

meaning: to be caused to be hated

examples.hebrew: שִׂנֵּאתִי אֶת הַמִּשְׂחָק הַזֶּה בְּגַלַּל הַחֲוָיָה הָרָעָה.
examples.transliteration: Sinéti et ha-mischák hazé begalál ha-chavayá ha-ra’á.
examples.translation: I treated this game with hatred because of the bad experience.

examples.hebrew: הוּא מְשַׂנֵּא אֶת הַסֵּפֶר בְּגַלַּל הַסּוֹף הַמַּר.
examples.transliteration: Hu mesané et ha-séfer begalál ha-sóf ha-mar.
examples.translation: He treats the book with hatred because of its bitter ending.

examples.hebrew: אֲשַׂנֵּא אֶת הַמִּשְׂימָה אִם לֹא תִּשְׁתַּפֵּר הַמַּצָּב.
examples.transliteration: Asané et ha-mismá im lo tishtapér ha-matzáv.
examples.translation: I will treat the task with hatred if the situation doesn’t improve.

sinea.notes: Pi'el intensifies the Pa'al meaning ('to hate') into 'to treat with hatred', suggesting a more deliberate or expressive act of enmity. This form is rare in modern spoken Hebrew, appearing mostly in literary or biblical contexts (e.g., Psalms 139:21, 'הֲלוֹא-מְשַׂנְאֶיךָ ה' אֶשְׂנָא' - 'Do I not hate those who hate You, O Lord?'). In contemporary usage, Pa'al ('to hate') is far more common, and Pi'el’s rarity limits its practical application.

idioms.translation: treating with a heart full of hatred
idioms.usage: הוּא מְשַׂנֵּא אֶת הַיָּרֵיב בְּלֵב מָלֵא אַחֲרֵי הַמַּחֲלוֹקֶת. (He treats the rival with a heart full of hatred after the dispute.)

meaning: to be caused to be hated

future.translation: I will be treated with hatred
you will be treated with hatred (m.s.)
you will be treated with hatred (f.s.)
he will be treated with hatred
she will be treated with hatred
we will be treated with hatred
you will be treated with hatred (m.pl.)
you will be treated with hatred (f.pl.)
they will be treated with hatred (m.)
they will be treated with hatred (f.)

examples.hebrew: הַמִּשְׂחָק שֻׂנֵּא עַל יְדֵי הַשַּׁחְקָנִים בִּגְלַל הַתָּקָנוֹת.
examples.transliteration: Ha-mischák suné al yedéi ha-shachkaním biglál ha-takanót.
examples.translation: The game was treated with hatred by the players because of the rules.

examples.hebrew: הַסֵּפֶר מְשֻׂנֵּא עַל יְדֵי הַקּוֹרְאִים בִּגְלַל הַסּוֹף.
examples.transliteration: Ha-séfer mesuné al yedéi ha-kor’ím biglál ha-sóf.
examples.translation: The book is treated with hatred by readers because of its ending.

examples.hebrew: הַמִּשְׂימָה יְשֻׂנֵּא אִם לֹא נְשַׁפֵּר אֶת הַתְּנָאִים.
examples.transliteration: Ha-mismá yesuné im lo neshapér et ha-tena’ím.
examples.translation: The task will be treated with hatred if we don’t improve the conditions.

sunea.notes: Pu'al is the passive form of Pi'el, turning 'to treat with hatred' into 'to be treated with hatred'. This form is rare in modern Hebrew, appearing mostly in literary or biblical contexts as an intensified passive of Pa'al ('to hate'). In contemporary usage, Nif'al ('to be hated') is more common, and Pu'al’s scarcity limits its practical application.
related_words: מְשֻׂנֵּא (treated with hatred, rare as adjective)

idioms.usage: הַסֵּפֶר הַזֶּה מְשֻׂנֵּא בְּעֵינֵי הַכֹּל בִּגְלַל הַדַּעַת שׁלוֹ. (This book is treated with hatred by all because of its opinion.)

meaning: to be caused to be hated

examples.translation: I hated myself after I failed the test.

examples.hebrew: הִיא מִתְשַׂנְּאָה כְּשֶׁהִיא רוֹאָה אֶת הַתּוֹצָאוֹת שֶׁלָּהּ.
examples.transliteration: Hi mitsan’áh kshehí ro’áh et ha-totza’ót sheláh.
examples.translation: She hates herself when she sees her results.

examples.hebrew: אֶתְשַׂנֵּא אִם אֶפְשֹׁט בַּמִּשְׂחָק הַזֶּה שׁוּב.
examples.transliteration: Etsané im efshót ba-mischák hazé shuv.
examples.translation: I will hate myself if I fail at this game again.

hitsanea.notes: Hitpa'el indicates reflexive action, turning 'to hate' (Pa'al) into 'to hate oneself'. This form is rare in modern Hebrew, appearing mostly in literary or poetic contexts rather than everyday speech. In contemporary usage, self-hatred is more typically expressed with Pa'al and a reflexive pronoun (e.g., 'שנאתי את עצמי' - 'I hated myself'), making Hitpa'el's application limited and uncommon.

idioms.translation: hated oneself with a heavy heart
idioms.usage: הוּא הִתְשַׂנֵּא בְּלֵב כָּבֵד אַחֲרֵי הַטָּעוּת שׁלוֹ. (He hated himself with a heavy heart after his mistake.)

meaning: to be caused to be hated

examples.hebrew: הִשְׂנֵאתִי אֶת הַיְּלָדִים אֶת הַמִּשְׂחָק בְּטָעוּת.
examples.transliteration: Hisnéti et ha-yeladím et ha-mischák betá’út.
examples.translation: I caused the children to hate the game by mistake.

examples.hebrew: הַסֵּפֶר מַשְׂנִיא אֶת הַקּוֹרְאִים אֶת הַסּוֹפֵר.
examples.transliteration: Ha-séfer masnía et ha-kor’ím et ha-sofér.
examples.translation: The book causes readers to hate the author.

examples.hebrew: אַשְׂנִיא אֶת הַצָּוֶת אֶת הַמִּשְׂימָה אִם לֹא נִשְׁתַּפֵּר.
examples.transliteration: Asnía et ha-tzavét et ha-mismá im lo nishtapér.
examples.translation: I will cause the team to hate the task if we don’t improve.

hasnia.notes: Hif'il is the causative form of Pa'al, shifting 'to hate' into 'to cause to hate'. It’s moderately common in modern Hebrew, often used to describe actions or situations that provoke hatred in others, such as making something detestable. Unlike Pi'el, Pu'al, and Hitpa'el, this form is not rare and has practical application in both spoken and written contexts.
related_words: מַשְׂנִיא (causing to hate, rare as adjective)

meaning: to be caused to be hated

examples.transliteration: Ha-mismá yusná im ha-tena’ím lo yishtaprú.

husna.notes: Huf'al is the passive form of Hif'il, turning 'to cause to hate' into 'to be caused to be hated'. It’s less common than Nif'al ('to be hated') in modern Hebrew but appears in formal or written contexts to emphasize a causative process leading to hatred. It contrasts with the simpler passive of Nif'al by highlighting an external influence or provocation.
