idioms.translation: caused to be hated in the eyes of the many
idioms.usage: הַמִּשְׂחָק הַזֶּה מֻשְׂנָא בְּעֵינֵי הַרַבִּים בִּגְלַל הַחֲוָיָה. (This game is caused to be hated in the eyes of the many because of the experience.)

meaning: to be caused to be hated

examples.translation: I fed the child with a spoon.

examples.hebrew: הוּא מַאֲכִיל אֶת הַכֶּלֶב כָּל בֹּקֶר.
examples.transliteration: Hu ma'akhil et ha-kelev kol boker.
examples.translation: He feeds the dog every morning.
I will feed the baby tomorrow.
Feed the cats!

haakhil.notes: Hif'il is the causative form of Pa'al, turning 'to eat' into 'to cause to eat' or 'to feed'. It’s commonly used in contexts involving feeding animals or children, and can also be used metaphorically (e.g., feeding information). It contrasts with Pa'al’s direct action of eating.

idioms.usage: הוּא מַאֲכִיל אֶת הַתִּינוֹק בְּכַפִּית. (Hu ma'akhil et ha-tinok bekhapit.) - He is spoon-feeding the baby.

meaning: to be caused to be eaten (rare)

yashev.root_meaning: Related to sitting, dwelling, or settling

examples.hebrew: יִשַּׁבְתִּי אֶת הָאֵזוֹר הַחָדָשׁ בְּתוֹךְ שָׁנָה.
examples.transliteration: Yishavti et ha-ezor ha-chadash betokh shanah.
examples.translation: I settled the new area within a year.
The government is settling the remote areas.

examples.hebrew: אֲנַחְנוּ נְיַשֵּׁב אֶת הָעִיר הַזֹּאת בְּעוֹד שָׁנָה.
examples.transliteration: Anachnu neyashev et ha-ir hazot be'od shanah.
examples.translation: We will settle this city within a year.
Settle the land quickly!

yashev.notes: Pi'el often intensifies or alters the root's meaning, turning 'to sit' into 'to settle' or 'to populate'. It’s commonly used in contexts involving colonization, community building, or establishing a presence in a new area, contrasting with Pa'al’s direct action of sitting.

idioms.usage: הַמִּתְיַשְּׁבִים יִשְּׁבוּ אֶת הָאָרֶץ הַחֲדָשָׁה. (Ha-mit'yashvim yishvu et ha-aretz ha-chadasha.) - The settlers settled the new land.

hit'yashev.root_meaning: Related to sitting, dwelling, or settling

examples.translation: I settled down at home after the hard day.
He is settling down on the couch.
I will settle down in an hour.
Settle down and calm yourselves!

hit'yashev.notes: Hitpa'el is the reflexive form of the verb, often used for actions done to oneself or reciprocal actions. In this case, it means 'to settle oneself down' or 'to calm oneself.' It’s commonly used in contexts involving personal relaxation or emotional calming.

idioms.translation: to settle on the chair (to take a seat comfortably)
idioms.usage: הוּא הִתְיַשֵּׁב עַל הַכִּסֵּא וְהִתְחִיל לִקְרֹא. (Hu hit'yashev al ha-kise ve'hitchil likro.) - He settled on the chair and started reading.

examples.translation: I met him at the café.
They meet every Friday.
If you want, we will meet tomorrow.
Meet at seven o'clock!

hifagesh.notes: Nif'al is often used for passive or reflexive actions. In this case, לְהִפָּגֵשׁ means 'to meet each other' or 'to be met.' It’s commonly used in social contexts to describe mutual meetings or gatherings.

idioms.usage: הֵם הִפָּגְשׁוּ בְּאֶמְצַע הַדֶּרֶךְ לְפַתֵּר אֶת הַבְּעָיָה. (Hem nifgeshu be'emtzah ha-derekh lefater et ha-be'ayah.) - They met halfway to solve the problem.

examples.translation: I met with them every Friday.
They meet regularly in the morning.
If you want, we will meet every week.
Meet whenever you want!

hitpagesh.notes: Hitpa'el often implies a reflexive or reciprocal action, and in this case, it emphasizes the repetitive or intensive nature of meeting, such as meeting regularly or in a group setting.

idioms.usage: הֵם הִתְפַּגְּשׁוּ בְּקָבוּעַ כָּל יוֹם שִׁשִּׁי. (Hem hitpagshu be'kavua kol yom shishi.) - They met regularly every Friday.

examples.translation: I was chosen for the role.
He is chosen to be the leader.
If you are chosen, you will have the opportunity.
Be chosen for the job!

hivacher.notes: Nif'al is the passive form of Pa'al, turning 'to choose' into 'to be chosen.' It’s commonly used in contexts involving selection or election, such as in competitions, elections, or appointments.

idioms.usage: הוּא נִבְחַר בְּטוֹב לַתַּפְקִיד. (Hu nivchar betov la'tafkid.) - He was chosen for good for the role.

meaning: to be caused to be chosen (rare)

future.translation: I will present myself for selection
You (m.s.) will present yourself for selection
You (f.s.) will present yourself for selection
He will present himself for selection
She will present herself for selection
We will present ourselves for selection
You (m.pl.) will present yourselves for selection
You (f.pl.) will present yourselves for selection
They (m.) will present themselves for selection
They (f.) will present themselves for selection

examples.translation: I presented myself for the role.
He presents himself for the competition.
If you want, you will present yourself for the position.
Present yourself for the job!

lehitbacher.notes: Hitpa'el is the reflexive form of the verb, often used for actions done to oneself. In this case, it means 'to present oneself for selection.' It’s commonly used in contexts involving job applications, elections, or competitions where individuals put themselves forward for consideration.

idioms.usage: הוּא הִתְבַּחֵר בְּטוֹב לַתַּפְקִיד. (Hu hitbacher betov la'tafkid.) - He presented himself for good for the role.

meaning: to be caused to be chosen (rare)

imperative.note: The imperative is rarely used for passive verbs like 'to be forgotten,' but theoretical forms are provided.

examples.translation: The story was forgotten long ago.
He is forgotten in the crowd.
If you don't remember, you will be forgotten.
It is good to be forgotten by the world.

lehishakeach.notes: Nif'al is the passive form of Pa'al, turning 'to forget' into 'to be forgotten.' It’s commonly used in contexts involving memory, history, or neglect, such as forgotten stories, people, or events.

idioms.translation: to be forgotten from the heart
idioms.usage: הַזִּכְרוֹנוֹת הַיְשָׁנִים נִשְׁכְּחוּ מֵהַלֵּב. (Ha'zikronot ha'yeshanim nishkechu mehalev.) - The old memories were forgotten from the heart.

meaning: to be caused to be forgotten (rare)

examples.hebrew: הוּא הִשְׁכִּיחַ אֶת הַכְּאֵב בְּעֶזְרַת הַמּוּזִיקָה.
examples.transliteration: Hu hishkiach et ha'ke'ev be'ezrat ha'muzika.
examples.translation: He caused the pain to be forgotten with the help of music.

examples.hebrew: הַמּוֹרָה מַשְׁכִּיחָה אֶת הַתַּלְמִידִים מֵהַבְּעָיוֹת שֶׁלָּהֶם.
examples.transliteration: Ha'mora mashkiacha et ha'talmidim meha'be'ayot shelahem.
examples.translation: The teacher causes the students to forget their problems.

examples.hebrew: אִם תִּרְצֶה, אַשְׁכִּיחַ לְךָ אֶת הַזִּכְרוֹנוֹת הָרָעִים.
examples.transliteration: Im tirzeh, ashkiach lecha et ha'zikronot ha'ra'im.
examples.translation: If you want, I will cause you to forget the bad memories.
Cause the transgression to be forgotten!

lehashkiach.notes: Hif'il is the causative form of the verb, turning 'to forget' into 'to cause to forget.' It’s often used in contexts where someone or something induces forgetfulness, such as through distraction, therapy, or time passing.
related_words: מַשְׁכִּיחַ (mashkiach) - one who causes to forget

idioms.translation: to cause the pain to be forgotten
idioms.usage: הַמּוּזִיקָה הִשְׁכִּיחָה אֶת הַכְּאֵב. (Ha'muzika hishkiacha et ha'ke'ev.) - The music caused the pain to be forgotten.

meaning: to be caused to be forgotten (rare)

examples.translation: She made the children happy at the party.
The gift makes me very happy.
If you want, I will make you happy.
Make the audience happy!

lehasmiach.notes: Hif'il is the causative form of the verb, turning 'to be happy' (Pa'al) into 'to make someone happy.' It’s commonly used in contexts where someone or something induces happiness, such as gifts, celebrations, or kind actions.

idioms.usage: הַשִּׁיר הִשְׂמִיחַ לֵב כֻּלָּם. (Ha'shir hismiach lev kulam.) - The song gladdened everyone's heart.

meaning: to be caused to be happy (rare)

examples.translation: He made everyone laugh with his stories.
The movie is very funny (makes one laugh a lot).
If you want, I will make you laugh.
Make the children laugh!

lehatzchik.notes: Hif'il is the causative form of the verb, turning 'to laugh' into 'to make laugh' or 'to cause laughter.' It’s commonly used in contexts where someone or something induces laughter, such as through humor, jokes, or amusing situations.

idioms.usage: הַקוֹמִיקַאי הִצְחִיק אֶת הַקָּהָל בְּמִשְׁךְ שָׁעָה. (Ha'komikai hitzchik et ha'kahal bemeshech sha'ah.) - The comedian made the audience laugh for an hour.

examples.translation: I watered the plants in the garden.

examples.hebrew: הוּא מַשְׁקֶה אֶת הַכֶּלֶב כָּל בֹּקֶר.
examples.transliteration: Hu mashkeh et ha'kelev kol boker.
examples.translation: He gives the dog water every morning.
I will give you a glass of water.
Give the children drink!

lehashkot.notes: Hif'il is the causative form, turning 'to drink' into 'to cause to drink' or 'to give drink.' It’s commonly used for watering plants or providing drinks to people or animals.

examples.translation: The house was seen from afar.
The stars are seen at night.
I will be seen in the picture.
Be seen in the right place!

leheraot.notes: Nif'al is often used for passive or stative actions. In this case, it means 'to be seen' or 'to appear,' indicating visibility or presence. It’s commonly used in contexts where something becomes visible or is perceived.

idioms.translation: to be seen in the eyes of the world
idioms.usage: הוּא רוֹצֶה לְהֵרָאוֹת בְּעֵינֵי הָעוֹלָם כְּאִישׁ מַצְלִיחַ. (Hu rotzeh lehera'ot be'einei ha'olam ke'ish matzliach.) - He wants to be seen in the eyes of the world as a successful man.

examples.hebrew: הוּא הוֹלִיךְ אֶת הַיְלָדִים לְבֵית הַסֵּפֶר.
examples.transliteration: Hu holich et ha'yeladim le'veit ha'sefer.
examples.translation: He led the children to school.

examples.hebrew: הַמַּדְרִיךְ מוֹלִיךְ אֶת הַקְּבוּצָה דֶּרֶךְ הַיַּעַר.
examples.transliteration: Ha'madrich molich et ha'kvutza derech ha'ya'ar.
examples.translation: The guide leads the group through the forest.
I will lead you to a safe place.
Lead the dog!

leholich.notes: The imperative form 'הוֹלֵךְ' can be ambiguous with the Pa'al form meaning 'go!', so it is often replaced with future tense (e.g., 'תּוֹלִיךְ') or other constructions in commands. The verb can also appear in the idiom 'לְהוֹלִיךְ שׁוֹלָל,' meaning 'to mislead' or 'to deceive.'

idioms.usage: הוּא הוֹלִיךְ אוֹתִי שׁוֹלָל. (Hu holich oti sholal.) - He misled me.

examples.translation: He activated the device.
The manager operates the new program.
I will activate the system in an hour.
Activate the facility!

lehaf'il.notes: Hif'il often serves as the causative form of Pa'al, turning 'to act' from Pa'al (לִפְעֹל) into 'to cause to act' or 'to activate' in Hif'il (לְהַפְעִיל). It’s commonly used in technological or operational contexts, such as activating devices or operating systems.

idioms.usage: הַמּוֹרֶה הִפְעִיל אֶת הַמַּחְשָׁבָה שֶׁל הַתַּלְמִידִים. (The teacher activated the students' minds.)

examples.translation: It was said that he would come tomorrow.
The matter is said clearly.
It will be said that this is unknown.
Be said in the name of the manager!

le'amer.notes: Nif'al is often the passive form of Pa'al. For אמר, it shifts from 'to say' in Pa'al (לֵאמֹר) to 'to be said' in Nif'al (לֵאָמֵר). It is commonly used in formal or narrative contexts to indicate something that was or will be said.

idioms.usage: הַתָּכְנִית נֶאֱמַר וְנַעֲשָׂה בְּדִיּוּק. (The plan was said and done precisely.)

meaning: to be caused to be said (rare)

examples.translation: He pleased the audience with his speech.
The manager pleases the employees.
I will please the family with gifts.
Please the children!

lehartsot.notes: Hif'il often serves as the causative form of Pa'al. For ר, it shifts from 'to want' in Pa'al (לִרְצוֹת) to 'to please' or 'to satisfy' in Hif'il (לְהַרְצוֹת). It is commonly used in formal or social contexts to indicate pleasing or satisfying someone.

idioms.usage: הַמּוּזִיקָה הִרְצְתָה אֶת הַלֵּב שֶׁלִּי. (The music pleased my heart.)

examples.translation: The book was given to him as a gift.
The time is given to us to learn.
They will be given additional time.
Be given the gift!

lenaten.notes: Nif'al is often the passive form of Pa'al. For נתן, it shifts from 'to give' in Pa'al (לָתֵת) to 'to be given' in Nif'al (לְהִנָּתֵן). It is commonly used in formal or narrative contexts to indicate something that was or will be given.

idioms.usage: הַיַּעַד נִתָּן לְהַשִּׂיג בְּמַאֲמָץ. (The goal can be achieved with effort.)

meaning: to be caused to be given (rare)

examples.hebrew: היא הֵיְשִׁינָה אֶת הַיֶּלֶד בְּשִׁירֵי עֶרֶשׂ.
examples.transliteration: Hi heyshina et ha'yeled be'shirei eres.
examples.translation: She put the child to sleep with lullabies.
The doctor puts the patient to sleep for the procedure.
I will put the animal to sleep for surgery.
Put the baby to sleep!

lehayshen.notes: Hif'il often serves as the causative form of Pa'al. For ישנ, it shifts from 'to sleep' in Pa'al (לִישׁוֹן) to 'to put to sleep' in Hif'il (לְהַיְשִׁין). It is commonly used in caregiving or medical contexts to indicate causing someone to sleep.

idioms.translation: to put the mind to sleep
idioms.usage: הַסִּרְטוֹן הֵיְשִׁין אֶת הַדַּעַת שֶׁלִּי. (The video put my mind to sleep.)

examples.translation: The project was carried out successfully.
The game is played all over the world.
The plan will be implemented next year.
Act responsibly!

lehifael.notes: Nif'al for 'פָּעַל' is often used in passive constructions, especially for actions or processes.

idioms.translation: to be acted upon in time of need
idioms.usage: הַתִּכְנוּן נִפְעַל בְּעֵת צָרָה. (The plan was implemented in time of need.)

examples.translation: He activated the device.
The machine operates the process.
I will activate the software.
Activate the button!

lefael.notes: Pi'el for 'פָּעַל' is less common than Hif'il but can be used for activating or operating machinery or systems.

idioms.translation: to activate in time of need
idioms.usage: הַמַּכְשִׁיר פִּעֵל בְּעֵת צָרָה. (The device activated in time of need.)

examples.translation: The device was activated successfully.
The process is operated by the machine.
The software will be activated soon.

lefu'al.notes: Pu'al is the passive form of Pi'el, used for actions where something is activated or operated.
similar_verbs: לְהוּפָעַל (lehufal) - to be caused to act

examples.translation: He acted upon the situation.
She acts responsibly.
I will act in difficult situations.
Act wisely!

lehitpa'el.notes: Hitpa'el for 'פָּעַל' can imply reflexive action or pretending to act, though it's less common.

future.translation: I will be caused to act
you will be caused to act (m.s.)
you will be caused to act (f.s.)
he will be caused to act
she will be caused to act
we will be caused to act
you will be caused to act (m.pl.)
you will be caused to act (f.pl.)
they will be caused to act (m.)
they will be caused to act (f.)

examples.translation: The device was operated by the technician.
The process is operated automatically.
The software will be operated soon.

lehufal.notes: Huf'al is the passive form of Hif'il, used for actions where something is caused to act or be operated. It is less common and often appears in formal or technical contexts.

examples.translation: I was invited to the party.
He is invited to the meeting.
I will be invited to the show.

lehuzman.notes: Huf'al is the passive form of Hif'il, used for actions where someone or something is invited. It is less common than other binyanim but appears in formal or written contexts.

examples.translation: The book was used successfully.
The device is used every day.
The software will be used soon.
It is good to use new devices.

lehishamesh.notes: The Nif'al form of the root שׁ-מ-שׁ indicates the passive form of using something. It is often used in contexts where an object or tool is being utilized, such as in technical or everyday settings.

idioms.usage: הוּא נִשְׁמַשׁ בְּסַכִּין לַחֲתֹךְ. (Hu nishmash be’sakin lachatoch.) - He used a knife to cut.

meaning: to be caused to be used (rare)

examples.translation: He gathered the group.
The teacher gathers the students.
I will gather the items.

lekanes.notes: The Pi’el form of כנס is an intensive form used for gathering or collecting people or things, widely used in both formal and informal contexts.

idioms.usage: הִיא כִּנְּסָה אֶת הַכֹּחוֹת לִפְנֵי הַמִּבְחָן. (Hi kinsa et ha’kochot lifnei ha’mivchan.) - She gathered her strength before the test.

examples.translation: The concept was explained simply.
The theory is explained in the book.
The question will be explained to us.

lehusbar.notes: Huf’al is the passive form of Hif’il, used here to indicate that something is being explained. It is less common and typically found in formal or technical contexts.

idioms.usage: הַנּוֹשֵׂא הֻסְבַּר בְּפֵרוּשׁ. (Ha’nose husbar be’ferush.) - The topic was explained explicitly.

examples.translation: The tension was felt in the room.
The joy is felt at the event.
The noise will be felt at night.

leheragesh.notes: The Nif’al form of רגש is passive, indicating that something (often an emotion or sensation) is being felt. It is common in contexts describing perceivable states.

idioms.translation: to be felt in the body
idioms.usage: הַכְּאֵב נִרְגַּשׁ בַּגּוּף. (Ha’ke’ev nirgash ba’guf.) - The pain was felt in the body.

examples.translation: He delayed the meeting.
She delays the response.
I will delay the flight.

leshahot.notes: The Pi’el form of שהה is an intensive form meaning to delay or linger, often used deliberately in modern Hebrew.

idioms.usage: הוּא שִׁהֵה אֶת הַזְּמַן בְּכַוָּנָה. (Hu shihe et ha’zman be’kavana.) - He delayed time on purpose.

examples.translation: He locked the door.
She locks the window.
I will lock the kitchen.

lena’el.notes: The Pi’el form of נעל is an intensive form meaning to lock, commonly used in modern Hebrew for securing doors, windows, or other enclosures.

idioms.usage: הֵם נִעֲלוּ אֶת הַבַּיִת לִפְנֵי הַטִּיּוּל. (Hem ni’alu et ha’bayit lifnei ha’tiyul.) - They locked the house before the trip.

examples.translation: Wealth abounded in the region.
The waters abound in the stream.
Joy will abound at the celebration.

lishpoa.notes: The Pa’al form of שפע is the basic form meaning to abound or overflow. It is less common in modern Hebrew but valid, often used in literary or poetic contexts.

idioms.usage: הַטֶּבַע שָׁפַע בְּשֶׁפַע. (Ha’teva shafa be’shefa.) - Nature abounded in abundance.

examples.translation: She paid attention in class.
He pays attention to a small thing.
I will pay attention to you.
Pay attention to me!

likshov.notes: Basic form of the root ["ק", "שׁ", "ב"] meaning 'to pay attention.' Commonly used in simple contexts requiring focus or listening, such as in a classroom setting, e.g., 'She paid attention in class.'

idioms.usage: הוּא קָשַׁב בְּקֶשֶׁב לַהוֹרָאוֹת. (Hu kashav be'keshev la'hora'ot.) - He paid close attention to the instructions.

examples.translation: He was faithful to his word.
She is believed in everyone's eyes.
We will be faithful to the family.
Be faithful to your friends!

leheamen.notes: Passive/reflexive form of the root ["א", "מ", "נ"], meaning 'to be faithful' or 'to be believed.' Often used in contexts of trust or loyalty, e.g., 'He was faithful to his word.'

idioms.usage: הוּא נֶאֱמַן לְעַצְמוֹ בְּכָל הַחְלָטוֹת. (Hu ne'eman le'atzmo be'chol ha'hachlatot.) - He is faithful to himself in all decisions.

examples.translation: The decision was announced yesterday.
The results are announced every day.
The prize will be announced soon.

lehukraz.notes: The Huf'al binyan indicates a passive form, often used for formal announcements or declarations.

idioms.usage: הַהַחְלָטָה הוּכְרְזָה רַשְׁמִית. (The decision was officially announced.)

examples.translation: The claim was contradicted by the researcher.
The statements are contradicted in the briefing.
The claim will be contradicted soon.

lehistar.notes: The Nif'al binyan often indicates a passive or reflexive action, here used for statements being contradicted.

idioms.usage: הַטַּעֲנָה נִסְתְּרָה בְּפוֹמְבִּי. (The claim was publicly contradicted.)

meaning: to be caused to be contradicted

examples.translation: The residents were warned about the danger.
The situation is warned about in reports.
The public will be warned soon.

lehuzhar.notes: The Huf'al form is rare and formal, often used to indicate being cautioned or alerted passively.

idioms.usage: הַתּוֹשָׁבִים הוּזְהֲרוּ מֵרֹאשׁ. (The residents were warned in advance.)

examples.translation: The device was invented this year.
The technology is invented every day.
The device will be invented soon.

lehumtza.notes: The Huf'al form indicates a passive action, often used for technological or creative inventions.

idioms.usage: הַמַּכְשִׁיר הוּמְצָא מֵחָדָשׁ. (The device was invented anew.)

examples.translation: He was angered by the situation.
She is angered when she hears the words.
I will be angered if you don't do this.

lehechareh.notes: The Nif'al form of חרה expresses a state of being angered or provoked, often in response to a situation or action.

idioms.usage: Commonly used to describe intense anger.

meaning: to be caused to be angry (rare)

examples.translation: The code was deciphered with the help of a computer.
The mystery is being deciphered now.
The document will be deciphered in a day.

lefu'anach.notes: The Pu'al form of פענח is a passive construction, typically used for codes, texts, or riddles that are being deciphered or solved.

meaning: to be caused to be deciphered (rare)

examples.translation: The foundations were undermined due to the earthquake.
The claim is being undermined in the discussion.
The plan will be undermined if we don’t act.

le'urar.notes: The Pu'al form of ערער denotes a passive state of being undermined or destabilized, often used for physical structures or abstract concepts like arguments.

meaning: to be caused to be undermined (rare)

examples.translation: The audience was persuaded by the speaker.
The proposal is easily persuaded.
They will be persuaded in the end.

leshukna.notes: The Pu'al form of שכנע is a passive construction indicating that someone or something is being persuaded, often by an external influence.

meaning: to be caused to be persuaded (rare)

examples.translation: The issue was clarified in a meeting.
The details are being clarified now.
The matter will be clarified tomorrow.

leburar.notes: The Pu'al form of ברר indicates a passive state of being clarified, often used for issues, facts, or details being made clear.

meaning: to be caused to be clarified (rare)

examples.translation: The student was challenged by a difficult test.
The team is being challenged by a new project.
If you are challenged, you will succeed.

lehit'atger.notes: Pu'al is the passive form of Pi'el, turning 'to challenge' into 'to be challenged'. It’s used when the subject is the recipient of a challenge or test, often in educational or competitive contexts.

idioms.translation: to be challenged in a difficult situation
idioms.usage: הוּא הִתְאַתְגֵּר בְּמַצָּב קָשֶׁה וְהִצְלִיחַ. (He was challenged in a difficult situation and succeeded.)

meaning: to be caused to be challenged

examples.translation: The project was managed successfully.
The negotiation is being conducted smoothly.
The process will be managed soon.

lehinahel.notes: Nif'al for 'נהל' indicates a passive action, often used in business or organizational contexts where processes or negotiations are being managed or conducted.

idioms.usage: הַפְּגִישָׁה נִהְנְהָה בְּאֹפֶן חָלָק. (The meeting was managed smoothly.)

meaning: to be caused to be managed

examples.translation: The flight was delayed by the weather.
The meeting is delayed until tomorrow.
The process will be delayed until next week.

lehimahem.notes: Nif'al for 'מהמ' indicates a passive action, often used for delays in schedules or processes. It's less common but appears in formal or logistical contexts.

idioms.usage: הַטִּיסָה נִמְהֲמָה עַל יְדֵי הַמַּזְגָּן. (The flight was delayed by the weather.)

meaning: to be caused to be delayed

examples.translation: The book was lifted from the table.
The flag is lifted every day.
The weight will be lifted soon.

lehuram.notes: Huf'al for 'רום' indicates a passive action, often used for physical lifting or elevation. It’s less common and typically appears in formal or literary contexts.

idioms.usage: הַדֶּגֶל הוּרַם לְמַעְלָה. (The flag was lifted upwards.)

examples.hebrew: הוּא הֶעֱבִיד אֶת הָעוֹבְדִים יֶתֶר עַל הַמִּדָּה.
examples.transliteration: Hu he'evid et ha'ovdim yeter al ha'mida.
examples.translation: He overworked the employees.
The king enslaved the people.
I will use the facility for the project's needs.

lehaavid.notes: The Hif'il form of the root ע-ב-ד shifts the meaning from 'to work' or 'to serve' (Pa'al) to 'to cause someone to work' or 'to enslave.' It is often used in contexts involving labor, servitude, or exploitation.

examples.translation: He laughed at himself.
I am laughing at my mistake.
We will laugh about it later.

lehitztachek.notes: The Hitpa'el form of the root צ-ח-ק implies a reflexive action, meaning 'to laugh at oneself.' It is often used in contexts of self-deprecation or humor directed at one's own actions.
related_words: מִצְטַחֵק (mitztachek) - one who laughs at himself

idioms.translation: to laugh at one's own expense
idioms.usage: הוּא הִצְטַחֵק עַל חֶשְׁבּוֹן עַצְמוֹ בַּפְּגִישָׁה. (Hu hitztachek al cheshbon atzmo ba'pgisha.) - He laughed at his own expense during the meeting.

examples.translation: He showed me the picture.
She shows the way.
I will show you the movie.
Show me the book!

leharot.notes: The Hif'il form of the root ר-א-ה shifts the meaning from 'to see' (Pa'al) to 'to cause to see' or 'to show.' It is a common verb in both formal and informal contexts.

idioms.usage: הוּא הִרְאָה לִי אֶת הַדֶּרֶךְ לַתַּחֲנָה. (Hu hir'a li et ha'derech la'tachana.) - He showed me the way to the station.

examples.translation: He strolled in the street.
I am strolling in the garden.
We will stroll in the park tomorrow.
Stroll slowly!

lehit'halech.notes: The Hitpa'el form of the root ה-ל-ך implies a leisurely or deliberate walk, often translated as 'to stroll' or 'to walk around.' It is used for casual or relaxed movement.

idioms.usage: הוּא הִתְהַלֵּךְ בְּחֹשֶׁךְ וְלֹא יָדַע לְאָן לָלֶכֶת. (Hu hit'halech be'choshech velo yada le'an lalechet.) - He walked in darkness and didn't know where to go.

lehavin.root_meaning: Related to understanding, discerning, or perceiving

examples.hebrew: הוּא בִּין אֶת הַהֶבְדֵּל בֵּין שְׁנֵי הַדְּבָרִים.
examples.transliteration: Hu bin et ha'hevdel bein shnei ha'dvarim.
examples.translation: He discerned the difference between the two things.
I understand the situation.

lehavin.notes: Regular verb in Pa'al binyan. Commonly used for both 'to discern' and 'to understand' depending on context.

idioms.translation: to discern between good and evil

examples.translation: I arranged a meeting with the friends.
He arranges meetings for the teams.

lehafgish.notes: Hif'il form shifts the Pa'al meaning 'to meet' to a causative 'to arrange a meeting'.

examples.translation: He served the king.
I use the device.

leshamesh.notes: Regular Pa'al verb. Can mean 'to serve' (e.g., a person) or 'to use' (e.g., an object).

examples.translation: I assembled the team.
He assembles the items.

lehachnis.notes: Hif'il form shifts Pa'al 'to enter' to causative 'to bring in' or 'to assemble'.

examples.translation: I thought that this was correct.
He thinks about the problem.

lesaver.notes: Regular Pa'al verb. Often used for opinions or suppositions.

idioms.translation: to show patience (lit. to think favorably)

examples.translation: I caused the children to stay.
He delays the program.

lehashhot.notes: Hif'il form of a root with guttural letters, shifting Pa'al 'to stay' to causative 'to cause to stay' or 'to delay'.

leamen.root_meaning: Related to trust, faith, or belief

examples.translation: I trust you.
He trusted his friend.
We will trust in God.
Trust in yourself!

leamen.notes: This verb is less common in Modern Hebrew and is often replaced by 'לִבְטוֹחַ' (to trust). It may appear in more formal or religious contexts.

idioms.usage: הוּא אָמַן בְּעַצְמוֹ לְהַצְלִיחַ. (Hu aman be'atzmo lehatsliach.) - He trusted himself to succeed.

lenacher.root_meaning: Related to being foreign or estranged

examples.translation: He was foreign in a strange land.
The customs are foreign to me.
If you travel, you will be foreign in a new place.
It is not good to be foreign in society.

lenacher.notes: This verb is less common in Modern Hebrew, with 'להיות זר' (to be foreign) being more frequently used. It may appear in literary or formal contexts.
similar_verbs: לִהְיוֹת זָר (lihyot zar) - to be foreign

examples.translation: The war will begin in a day.
He begins the journey.
You will begin new studies.
It is good to begin at a good time.

letachel.notes: This verb is archaic and rarely used in Modern Hebrew, where 'לְהַתְחִיל' (Hif'il) is the standard form for 'to begin'. It may appear in biblical or poetic contexts.

examples.translation: She arranged the room.
I arrange the books.
We will arrange the documents tomorrow.
Arrange the table!

lesader.notes: The Pi'el form of the root ס-ד-ר is commonly used in Modern Hebrew for arranging or organizing physical objects or abstract concepts.

idioms.usage: הוּא סִדֵּר אֶת הַדְּבָרִים בְּסֵדֶר מוֹפְתִי. (Hu sider et ha'dvarim be'seder mofeti.) - He arranged things in perfect order.

likdom.root_meaning: Related to preceding or being early

examples.translation: The sun preceded the moon.
He precedes me by a year.
I will precede the meeting.
Precede the meeting!

likdom.notes: The Pa'al form of the root ק-ד-מ is used in Modern Hebrew to indicate preceding in time or order. It is moderately common.

idioms.usage: הַשֶּׁמֶשׁ קָדְמָה לַיָּרֵחַ בְּזְמַן. (Ha'shemesh kadma la'yareach be'zman.) - The sun preceded the moon in time.

examples.translation: The rain ceased suddenly.

examples.hebrew: הַמּוּזִיקָה פּוֹסֶקֶת כָּל לַיְלָה בְּשָׁעָה עֶשֶׂר.
examples.transliteration: Ha'muzika poseket kol laila be'sha'a eser.
examples.translation: The music stops every night at ten o'clock.
If you don't stop, I will leave the room.
Stop talking now!

pasek.notes: The verb לפסוק in Pa'al is used to indicate the cessation of an action or state, such as stopping an activity or an event coming to an end. It is commonly used in both formal and informal contexts.
related_words: פּוֹסֵק (posek) - one who ceases or a decider in Jewish law

idioms.usage: הוּא פָּסַק מִלְּדַבֵּר בְּאֶמְצַע הַדִּבּוּר. (Hu pasak mil'daber be'emtzah ha'dibur.) - He stopped speaking in the middle of the speech.

shaar.root_meaning: Related to remaining or being left

examples.translation: He remained at home.
She remains at her workplace.
We will remain without water.
Remain here!

shaar.notes: The verb לִשְׁאֹר in Pa'al is used to indicate remaining or being left behind. It is commonly used in contexts where something or someone stays in a particular state or place. Note that the root שׁ-א-ר has a guttural letter (א), which affects conjugation patterns, particularly in the imperative and future tenses.

idioms.usage: הוּא שָׁאַר בְּלִי כֶּסֶף. (Hu sha'ar bli kesef.) - He remained without money.

examples.hebrew: הוּא יָצַע לִי לִקְנוֹת אֶת הַסֵּפֶר.
examples.transliteration: Hu yatza li liknot et ha'sefer.
examples.translation: He advised me to buy the book.
She advises her friends.
I will advise you to see a doctor.
Advise me how to do this!

yatza.notes: The verb לִיצֹעַ in Pa'al is used to indicate giving advice or counsel. It is less common in modern Hebrew and often replaced by לְהַצִיעַ (lehatzi'a). However, it appears in biblical and formal contexts.

idioms.usage: הוּא יָצַע עֵצָה טוֹבָה. (Hu yatza etza tova.) - He gave good advice.

examples.translation: He sought the key.
She seeks the truth.
I will seek the answer in the book.
Seek the way!

chafas.notes: The verb לַחְפֹּשׂ in Pa'al is used to indicate seeking or searching for something. It is commonly used in both literal and figurative contexts, such as looking for physical objects or seeking knowledge or truth. Note that the root ח-פ-ש has a guttural letter (ח), which affects pronunciation and conjugation patterns, particularly in the imperative and future tenses.
similar_verbs: לְחַפֵּשׂ (lechapes) - to search (Pi'el form of the same root)

idioms.usage: הוּא חָפַשׂ אֶת הָאֱמֶת בְּכָל מָקוֹם. (Hu chafas et ha'emet be'chol makom.) - He sought the truth everywhere.

meaning: to be caused to be sought (rare)

examples.translation: He tied the rope.
She ties the laces.
I will tie the dog to the tree.
Tie the package!

kashar.notes: The verb לִקְשֹׁר in Pa'al is used to indicate tying or binding something physically, such as ropes or laces. It can also be used metaphorically, as in tying relationships or connections. The root ק-ש-ר is regular and follows standard Pa'al conjugation patterns.

idioms.usage: הוּא קָשַׁר קֶשֶׁר חָזָק. (Hu kashar kesher chazak.) - He tied a strong knot.

meaning: to be caused to be tied (rare)

examples.translation: I revealed the secret.
He reveals the truth.
I will reveal the plans.
Reveal the document!

liglot.notes: גלה primarily means 'to reveal' or 'to uncover' in modern Hebrew. It can also historically mean 'to go into exile,' though this usage is rare today.

idioms.usage: הוּא גָּלָה אֶת הַקַּלְפִּים שֶׁלּוֹ. (He revealed his cards.)

examples.translation: I caused the candidates to be selected.
He is causing the choices to be made.
I will cause the team to be selected.
Cause the candidate to be selected!

lehavchir.notes: The Hif'il form of בחר is rare and theoretical, implying a causative action ('to cause to choose'). The common form for 'to select' or 'to choose' is בחר in Pa'al (לִבְחֹר).

examples.translation: I caused the students to assist.
She causes the friends to help.
I will cause the family to assist.
Cause the team to assist!

leha'zir.notes: The Hif'il form of עזר is rare and theoretical, implying 'to cause to help.' The common form for 'to assist' is עזר in Pa'al (לַעְזֹר).

examples.translation: I reminded her of the date.
He reminds about the task.
I will remind you of the meeting.
Remind about the program!

lehazkir.notes: In Hif'il, זכר means 'to remind,' a common causative form of the Pa'al 'to remember' (לִזְכֹּר). It is widely used in everyday Hebrew.

idioms.translation: to remind someone of what they forgot
idioms.usage: הִזְכַּרְתִּי לוֹ אֶת מָה שֶׁשָּׁכַח. (I reminded him of what he forgot.)

examples.translation: The city perished in the fire.
He is perishing from home.
I will perish without water.
Perish the enemy!

lishmod.notes: Pa'al is the simple active form. For שמד, it means 'to perish' or 'to be destroyed'. It can also mean 'to destroy' in some contexts, but this entry focuses on the intransitive sense.

examples.translation: He waited for the bus.
She is waiting for her friend.
I will wait for you.
Wait for me!

lechakot.notes: Pa'al is the simple active form. For חכה, it means 'to wait' or 'to expect'. It’s a common verb in daily use, often for waiting for people or events.

examples.hebrew: הוּא הוֹשִׁיב אֶת הַיֶּלֶד עַל הַכִּסֵּא.
examples.transliteration: Hu hoshev et ha'yeled al ha'kise.
examples.translation: He seated the child on the chair.
She is seating the students.
I will seat the guests.
Seat everyone!

lehoshev_hifil.notes: Hif'il is the causative form. For ישב, it shifts from 'to sit' in Pa'al to 'to cause to sit' or 'to seat'. Often used for arranging seating or placing people.

examples.hebrew: הוּא הֶעֱמִיד אֶת הַסֵּפֶר עַל הַמַּדָּף.
examples.transliteration: Hu he'emid et ha'sefer al ha'madaf.
examples.translation: He positioned the book on the shelf.
She is positioning the chair.
I will position the device.
Position the flags!

leha'amid.notes: Hif'il is the causative form. For עמד, it shifts from 'to stand' in Pa'al to 'to cause to stand' or 'to position'. Used for placing objects or people in a standing position.

examples.translation: He developed the program.
She is developing the project.
I will develop the idea.
Develop the page!

lepateach.notes: Pi'el often indicates an intensive or causative action. For פתח, it shifts from 'to open' in Pa'al to 'to develop' or 'to open up' in a more intensive sense. Commonly used in contexts like software or project development.

meaning: to be caused to be opened (rare)

examples.translation: They cooked the rice.
I am cooking the soup.
They will cook the meat.
Cook the vegetables!

bashal.notes: While the root ב.ש.ל primarily means 'to cook' in modern Hebrew, it can also mean 'to ripen' in certain contexts, especially for fruits or crops. However, 'to ripen' is more commonly expressed with the Hif'il form לְהַבְשִׁיל (lehabsheel).

idioms.translation: to cook with cold blood (to act calmly under pressure)
idioms.usage: הוּא בִּשֵּׁל בְּדַם קַר בְּמַצָּבִים קָשִׁים. (He acted calmly under pressure in difficult situations.)

examples.translation: He made the children dance.
The teacher makes the students dance.
I will make the dog dance.
Make the cat dance!

lerakid.notes: The Hif'il form of רקד implies causation, meaning 'to cause someone or something to dance,' often used in playful or instructional contexts.

idioms.translation: to make the cat dance (to attempt something challenging)
idioms.usage: הוּא נִסָּה לְהַרְקִיד אֶת הַחֲתוּל בְּלִי הַצְלָחָה. (He tried to make the cat dance without success.)

examples.translation: He made the dog jump.
The teacher makes the students jump.
I will make the cat jump.
Make the dog jump!

lekapetz.notes: The Hif'il form of קפץ indicates causation, meaning 'to cause someone or something to jump,' often used in playful or physical contexts.
related_words: מַקְפֵּץ (makpétz) - one who causes to jump

examples.translation: He made the bird fly.
The boy is flying a kite.
I will fly the kite.
Make the bird fly!

lehafif.notes: The Hif'il form of עוף means 'to cause to fly,' commonly used for making birds fly or flying kites (עֲפִיפוֹן, afifon).

leha'alot.root_meaning: Related to going up or ascending

examples.translation: He raised the flag.
The teacher raises the question.
I will raise the suitcase.
Raise the flag!

leha'alot.notes: The Hif'il form of עלה means 'to raise' or 'to lift,' used both physically (e.g., lifting an object) and metaphorically (e.g., raising a topic).

idioms.usage: הַמְּפַקֵּד הֶעֱלָה אֶת הַמּוֹרָל שֶׁל הַחַיָּלִים. (The commander raised the soldiers' morale.)

examples.translation: He dropped the book.
The boy drops the ball.
I will drop the plate.
Drop the ball!

lehafil.notes: The Hif'il form of נפל means 'to cause to fall' or 'to drop,' used both literally (e.g., dropping an object) and figuratively (e.g., causing failure).

idioms.translation: to drop the curtain (to reveal something)
idioms.usage: הוּא הִפִּיל אֶת הַמַּסָּךְ עַל הַתָּכְנִית. (He revealed the plan.)

examples.translation: The government centralized the services.
He is centralizing the efforts.
I will centralize the documents.
Centralize the efforts!

lerakez.notes: The Pi'el form of the root ר-כ-ז typically means to centralize or concentrate something, often used in administrative or organizational contexts.

idioms.usage: הַצָּוֶת רִכֵּז מַאֲמָצִים לְהַשְׁלִים אֶת הַפְּרוֹיֶקְט. (The team centralized efforts to complete the project.)

la'akosh.root_meaning: Related to being stubborn or obstinate

examples.translation: He was stubborn in his opinion.
She is stubborn in every situation.
Don't be stubborn about small matters.
Be stubborn in your ways!

la'akosh.notes: The Pa'al form of the root ע-ק-ש typically means to be stubborn or obstinate, often used in everyday contexts to describe behavior.

idioms.usage: הוּא עָקַשׁ בַּדַּעַת שֶׁלּוֹ. (He was stubborn in his opinion.)

examples.translation: He donated to the organization.
She donates to charity.
I will donate to the new project.
Donate to this cause!

lehatrim.notes: The Hif'il form of the root ת-ר-ם typically means to donate or contribute, often used in contexts of charity or support.

idioms.translation: to donate for the sake of
idioms.usage: הוּא הִתְרִים לְמַעַן הַצְּדָקָה. (He donated for the sake of charity.)

lehibalev.root_meaning: Related to confusion or mixing up

examples.translation: The student was confused on the test.
She is confused in every case.
I will be confused without instructions.
Be confused in difficult situations!

lehibalev.notes: The Nif'al form of the root ב-ל-ב typically means to be confused or mixed up, often used in contexts of misunderstanding or disorientation.

idioms.translation: to be confused in a situation
idioms.usage: הוּא נִבְלַב בְּמַצָּב הַחֵרוּם. (He was confused in the emergency situation.)

lehavriach.root_meaning: Related to running away or escaping

examples.translation: He caused the animal to escape.
She smuggles the goods.
I will cause the child to escape.
Cause the animals to escape!

lehavriach.notes: The Hif'il form of the root ב-ר-ח typically means to cause something or someone to escape, often used in contexts of smuggling or helping someone flee.

idioms.usage: הוּא הִבְרִיחַ סְחוֹרוֹת לְאַרְצוֹת הַבְּרִית. (He smuggled goods to the United States.)

examples.translation: He whispered to himself quietly.
She whispers to herself when she thinks.

lehitchashesh.notes: The Hitpa'el form implies a reflexive action, often used for whispering to oneself or murmuring internally.

examples.translation: He counted the stars.
She is counting the numbers.
I will count the money.
Count the pages!

lispor.notes: Pa'al is the simple active form. For ספר, it primarily means 'to count' or 'to number'. It can also mean 'to tell a story' in some contexts, but this entry focuses on counting.

meaning: to be caused to be counted (rare)
